Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Where were they? A. They ran in and out of my yard—there was a place for them to go in—they did not wander two hundred yards from my door.

WALTER CAMPBELL (police-sergeant E 16.) I stopped the two prisoners in Guildford-street, on the 21st of January, about eleven o'clock in the forenoon, coming in a direction from Clerkenwell—Dean had two hens and a cock in a bundle, and Besmore had one hen secreted under his jacket—they said they had bought them of an Irishman, in Newgate-market—these are the fowls—there was another boy with them.

ROBERT BARKERE
re-examined. These are my fowls. I saw them safe a little after ten o'clock, at my door—the prisoners, and another boy, were standing there for about ten minutes.
Dean's Defence. I bought the fowls of a man, for 5s. 6d., and I asked this lad to carry one.
Besmore. I met this boy—he asked me to carry one.
(Dean received a good character.)

DEAN—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Six Weeks.

BESMORE—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined One Month.

730.
CAROLINE REYNOLDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of January, 6 bags, value 5s., the goods of
Charles Bunyard and another, her masters.

JOHN SMITH . I am in the service of Messrs. Charles Bunyard and Francis Metcalf, in Britannia-street East. The prisoner was in their service, to pick peas—on the 24th of January I found in the privy six bags concealed in one corner, a little before nine o'clock at night—I was ordered to watch, and observed the prisoner run across the yard—I followed her, and when she was about to leave the shop I stopped her—she threw down these six bags, from under her shawl, on some other bags—she said, "Pray don't, Mr. Smith; pray let me go"—I let her go, and the next morning she did not come to work as usual, but Mr. Bunyard sent for her—I know these bags—she said she had taken them from a shelf in the lower warehouse.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. is the place where you saw the bags, open to all the people in the house? A. Yes—I stopped her at the shop door, which is perhaps twenty yards from that place—there is a back entrance, but the females do not go that way.
COURT. Q. Are you quite sure the prisoner said they were taken from the shelf? A. Yes.

JOHN KIRSHAW (police-constable G 128.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 25th of January—I asked her why she did not come to work—she said she was very ill—I said she must go along; with me, and she said, "I know what you want me for."
Cross-examined. Q. You knew where to find her? A. I had a wrong direction at first—I searched the house, but found nothing.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Ten

731.
JAMES JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of January, 6 1/4oz. of cigars, value 10s., the goods of
Woolf Jacobs.

ABIGAIL JACOBS . I am the wife of Woolf Jacobs, who keeps a tobac
conist's shop in Featherstone-street. On the afternoon of the 9th of Janu
ary I was sitting in the back room—I lifted up my head, and saw the pri
soner in the shop—he took his arm from over the rail, and walked out—I went after him, and in passing I saw the place of these cigars vacant in the window—I never lost sight of him—I said to him, "You have robbed me"—he said, "I have not"—I said, "If you have not, you will not hesitate to come back"—I seized him—he said, "If you will let me go, I will return"—I would not, and after a struggle he came back—he struck me several blows, and then he took off his hat, took out the cigars, and said, "Here is what I have got; now let me go"—I would not—he struck me, and threw the cigars behind the counter—he then struck me again several times, and got away—I overtook him again near the same place—he struggled, but some persons came up, and he was taken.

DANIEL COTTELL . I live in Brown's-lane, Spitalfields. I saw the pri
soner come out of Jacobs's shop, and saw him strike the witness—I took hold of him, and took him to the station-house.

EDWARD HUTTON (police-constable G 219.) I was at the station-house when the prisoner was brought there—I went, and found one hundred and eight cigars strewed on the floor behind the prosecutor's counter.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going past—she came out and accused me of being in her shop—I said, I had not—she took hold of my collar—I took hold of her hand merely to remove it—I went back and said, "You see I have nothing about me, and I suppose now you will let me go"—I came out again, and she again laid hold of my coat—the witness came and took me.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Two Months.

732.
MICHAEL VARNELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of January, 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch chain, value 6d.; 2 seals, value 3s.; and 3 watch keys, value 6d.; the goods of
Richard Clempson.

RICHARD CLEMPSON . I live in Little Mary-le-bone-street, and am a groom out of place—I was at the Plasterer's Arms, in Mary-le-bone-street, on the 16th of January—I left my watch in the privy there, by mistake—I went to get it, and heard something about the prisoner—I went to him in a public-house in Beaumont Mews, and asked if he had seen any thing of my watch—he said no, he had not—I told him where I had left it, and said I thought he must be the man that had got it—this is my watch—(looking at it.)
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you quite sure you told him where you had left it? A. Yes—I never saw him before.

WILLIAM GARDENER . I live at Mr. Walter's, a pawnbroker in High-street, Mary-le-bone—this watch was pawned by the prisoner on the 16th of January between six and seven o'clock, as near as I can say—he wanted 1l.—I lent him 15s.—he said it was his own—he gave his address John Harris, 23, Lisson-street.

WILLIAM AINSLIE (police-constable D 114.) I took the prisoner—Clempson said, "I think you are the man that has got my watch"—the prisoner said, "I have not had your watch, nor seen it"—I told the prisoner next day, that I had found it, and he must go with me to the pawnbroker—he was very willing to do that—the pawnbroker said he was the man—the prisoner said he was a liar, and he had never been in the shop—I took him back, and then he said he had pawned it.
Cross-examined. Q. What became of the prisoner after you let him go? A. I took him again the next day, in Beaumont Mews.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined One Month.

733.
WILLIAM HENRY DAVIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of January, 4 half-crowns, and 3 shillings, the monies of
Henry Watkins.

KEZIAH WATKINS . I am the wife of Henry Watkins, and live in Russel-court, Bridge-street—we keep a shop, and have a parlour at the back—on the 21st of January, between eight and nine o'clock in the even
ing, I heard a noise on the counter—I looked, and saw the prisoner behind the shop door, putting his arm across the counter; and his hand was on a shelf, where I had left 4 half-crowns and 3 shillings—he went out
—I ran after him and called "Stop thief"—he was stopped by Harrison, without my losing sight of him.

GEORGE HARRISON (police-constable T 120.) I was in Vinegar-yard, and saw the prisoner running towards me—he turned and ran back—I took him, and found 5d. and a knife on him—the money has not been found.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going through the court—I saw a young man come running out of the prosecutor's shop, and he knocked my hat off—I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I ran after him.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

734.
SAMUEL ALEXANDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of January, 2 pairs of boots, value 9s.; and 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Samuel Janes.

WILLIAM UDELL . I live in North-street, Maida-hill, opposite Mr. Janes, a shoemaker. At eight o'clock on the evening of the 29th of January, I was looking through my shop window, and saw the prisoner behind the counter, in Mr. Janes' shop, and near the window—I ran over, and found him at the further end of the counter with a pair of shorn in his hand—he attempted to remove some boots, but I prevented him, and gave him in charge—the policeman took two pairs of boots out of his pockets.
JOHN ROCKET (police-constable D 33.) I was sent for, and found on him two pairs of boots.
SAMUEL JANES . These are my property.
Prisoner. I hope you will be merciful.

GUILTY .* Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months, and
Whipped.

735.
WILLIAM GRIFFITHS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of January, 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
David Laing, from his person.

DAVID LAING . I live in Lark Hall-lane, Clapham, and am an attorney. On the 22nd of January, I was in St. Martin's-lane—I felt a tug at my pocket—I turned instantly, and saw the prisoner about a foot behind me, with both his hands behind him, and my handkerchief in his hand—I said, "How came you by that handkerchief?"—he said, "What handkerchief?" I said, "The one you took out of my pocket"—he threw it down—I took it up, and placed my arm round his neck—he struggled, and nearly threw me down in the mud, but I put out my right hand, and a friend assisted me—I got up again, and put my arm round his neck again—he struck me about the head and body, and called to some companions to help him, but I held him till the officer came and took him.

THOMAS CROSS . I am a constable. I was coming down St. Martin's-lane—there was a crowd, and the prosecutor was calling "Police"—I ran up, and collared the prisoner—he said, "I will go with you, but I am not going to be lugged about for nothing"—here is the handkerchief, it was not soiled at all—he was struggling very hard with the prosecutor.

WILLIAM HENRY WYATT . I was walking down St. Martin's-lane, arm in arm with the prosecutor—he turned round, and saw his handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—he dropped it, and said some boys had taken it out—the prosecutor laid hold of him, he struck him in the face, and his hat fell off—I took it up, and collared the prisoner.
Prisoners Defence. I was coming down St. Martin's-lane—I saw two

lads behind the gentleman, and one passed by him very quickly—the gen
tleman accused me of taking his handkerchief, which I did not—he took me by the neck—I scufiled, and he nearly fell—I did not strike him.
GUILTY .* Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

736.
ROBERT SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of January, 1 time-piece, value 2l., the goods of
John Westaway.

EDWIN WESTAWAY . I live with my father, John Westaway, in Gower-street North—he is a watch-maker. On Thursday night, the 24th of Ja
nuary, I was in the parlour, and saw somebody stepping out of the shop—I told my brother, and he went out.

HENRY WESTAWAY . I was told of this by my brother, and missed a time-piece from a stand in front of the shop, near the door—I saw the prisoner go off the step of the door, and throw the time-piece against the chapel—I pursued, and took him—I had not lost sight of him at all.

Prisoner. When he overtook me in Euston-square, he said, "Tell me where the property is, and I will not prosecute you." Witness. No, I did not—when I took him, he said, "Pray don't—pray don't"—I said, "Pray don't what?" and the officer came and took him.
JOHN WESTAWAY . This time-piece was on a stand in my shop—it had been left me to repair.

JOHN ROUSE (police-constable E 24.) I was on duty, and took the pri
soner.
Prisoner. I hope you will recommend me to mercy.

GUILTY .* Aged 22.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Transported for Seven Years.

737.
THOMAS MATTHEWS and
WILLIAM WALKER were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 15th of January, 2 locks, value 8d;2 keys, value 4d.;1 latch, value 4d.;1 ornament, value 4d.; and 1 vice, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
John William Wintle.

JOHN WI LLIAM WINTLE . I keep a general shop in Kingsland-road. On the 15th of January I found the prisoners in custody at the station-house—I found these articles in possession of the officer—the vice has not been found—I know this ornament—I had locks and keys like these, but I cannot swear to them.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you a dealer in marine-stores? A. No—I never dealt in marine-stores in my life, but I have it written up to save myself from the fangs of informers—I would not swear to this ornament, but I had such a one—it represents the binding of our Saviour.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) On the evening of the 15th of January I saw the two prisoners with another, near the prosecutor's shop in Kingsland-road, where there were a great many articles of ironmongery on a board—I watched, and saw them all three pass, and take something off the board—they went past, then turned back, and I saw the prisoners take two locks—I then followed them to a marine-store shop in Essex-street—the prisoners went in to sell the things—I went and took them in the shop—Matthews had a file and this leaden ornament—Walker had these two locks and keys, and latch—the other one escaped—Matthews said another boy gave him this ornament, and then he said he picked it up.
Cross-examined. Q. How far were you from them? A. Standing
right opposite the shop—they might have seen me, but they did not know me, as I was in plain clothes.
(Matthews received a good character.)

MATTHEWS*—
GUILTY .—Aged 15. WALKER*—
GUILTY .—Aged 13.

Confined One Month and
Whipped.

738.
JOHN FLETCHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Janu
ary, 1 pair of boots, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
George Savage, his master.

GEORGE SAVAGE . I live in Tottenham Court-road, and am a shoe
maker—the prisoner was my errand-boy. On the 30th of January I re
marked, when he went out to breakfast, that one of his pockets appeared bulky—he had his great coat on—when he came back he put his great coat on a shelf, and about an hour before dinner-time I felt his great coat, and found in it something like boots or shoes—I then went and spoke to the policeman, the prisoner went out, and the policeman brought him back with these boots.

JOHN FORD (police-sergeant F 20.) I waited outside, and took the pri
soner as he was going to dinner—he was putting on his great coat as he came out—he walked from the door buttoning it up—I went to him and asked what he had got in his pocket—he said a pair of boots which he was going to take to Rathbone-place—I asked what house—he said, "No. 18"—I asked him the name of the person—he said he did not know—I asked if they were paid for—he said "Yes"—I asked how much—be said, "6s. 6d."—I asked if he had paid his master the money—he said "Yes"—I took" them from him, took him back to the shop, and asked Mr. Savage if he had given him a pair of boots to take to Rathbone-place, the prisoner then said, "No, I did not say so, I was going to take them to my mother."

GEORGE SAVAGE
re-examined. His mother lives in Well-street, which is rather nearer to Rathbone-place than where I reside—he bore a good character before—he had only entered my service on the Saturday before.
Prisoner. What I had in my pocket at breakfast time was my breakfast.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
739.
JAMES EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of January, 1 cloak, value 3l. 3s., the goods of
Henry Girdlestone.

WILLIAM BRIMBLECOMBE . I am a policeman. On the 23rd of January I met the prisoner in the Edgeware-road with a bundle—I asked what he bad got—he said his coat which he had taken out of pawn—he afterwards said a man gave it him to carry—there were two more men with him, who ran tway—I took him to the station-house, and found this cloak in the bundle
HENRY GIRDLESTONE . I am a medical student. left this cloak at Mr. Howlett's—it is mine.

HENRY HOWLBTT . I am a surgeon, and live in Cambridge-terrace, On the 23rd of January I went out, about one o'clock, and took this cloak—when I came home, about two o'clock, I left it in a small room adjoining my surgery, and told the boy to hang it up—I went in again at four o'clock, and saw it still on a chair—I went there again at six o'clock, and my impression was, that it was there then, but I will not be certain.
Prisoner. I met two young men, who said they would give me 6d. to carry the bundle to Oxford-street.
, (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

740.
ELLEN DERVERNEY was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN WILSON . I am a French polisher, and live in Ashley-street, King's-cross. The prisoner was occasionally employed by us to wash or clean—on the 12th of January I sent her for a pot of porter for supper, which came to 3d.—I gave her half a sovereign, and she was to bring me the change—she returned with the porter, and placed what I supposed was the change on the table while I was reading—in a little time I went to take up the change, and there was but 3d.—I spoke to her about it—she said the landlady had only given her 3d., and then she said if I would let her go she would get me the change—I said I would not without she would let me go with her—she refused that, and I took her to the public-house—she denied that the landlady had given her any more than 3d.

SARAH VEREY . I am the wife of the publican. On the 12th the pri
soner came for some porter—I served her—she put down half a sovereign, and T gave her the change, three half-crowns, two sixpences, one shilling, and 3d.
Prisoner. You did not give me more than 3d. Witness. What I have said is quite true.

JAMES LUCAS . I am an officer. The prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge—I took her to the landlady, who said she gave her the full change—the prisoner denied it—I took her to the station-house.
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

741.
WILLIAM GEORGE TAYLOR and
THOMAS TREW
were indicted for stealing, on the 2nd of January, 268lbs. weight of iron, value 60s., the goods of
Samuel Palmer Gladstone.

JOHN HABGOOD (police-constable K 109.) I was in Robin Hood-lane, Poplar, on the 2nd of January, at half-past seven o'clock in the evening. I observed the two prisoners enter a marine store-dealer's with something very heavy on their backs—I went in, and Trew had just put down a bundle on the counter—I asked him what he had got—he said he did not know—Taylor then said that he had employed him to carry some iron be
longing to his master, and was to give him 6d. for his trouble—I sent for assistance, and took them.

SAMUEL PALMER GLADSTONE . This iron is my property, and was taken out of my shop in the East India-road. I am a shipwright—the policeman says there is 268lbs. of this, but I have not weighed it—I do not know the prisoners.
JOHN GOODIFF . I am a smith in the service of Mr. Gladstone, I know this iron—it was taken from his shop—I saw it safe a few days before against the shop door.

GEORGE JAMES SIBUN . I am a coal-merchant and a carman. Taylor is a servant of mine, and had at all times the key of my stable—when they were taken, Taylor said he took the iron from my stable—I did not see it there, nor do I know that it was there—my stable is close to the prosecutor's.
EDWARD SHAW (police-sergeant E 14.) I went to search Mr. Sibun's premises, and found 64lbs. of this iron belonging to the prosecutor.

JOHN SIMPSON (police-constable K 230.) I produce part of the iron found at Mr. Sibun's, and when Taylor was leaving the marine-store shop, he had 2lbs. of this iron in his pocket—he said he might as well leave it all, and pulled this out.
Taylor's Defence, I employed this prisoner to carry this iron, and was to pay him sixpence—it had been lying in Mr. Sibun's stable some
time
(Taylor received a good character.)

TAYLOR—
GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Six Months TREW*—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Year.

742.
JAMES MITCHELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of January, 1 coat, value 4s.; 1 snuff-box, value 4d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 8d., the goods of
George Henry Flintoft Easterby.

GEORGE HENRY FLINTOFT EASTIRBY . I lived in George-street, St. Giles's, the prisoner lodged there. On the night of the 17th of January, he slept in another bed at the foot of mine, and went to bed after me—I missed my coat when I was awoke by my landlady crying out, "The old man's coat is stolen off the bed"—it was between one and two o'clock in the day—I had been very afflicted all night, and felt heavy for sleep—this is the coat—this handkerchief was in the pocket

MARGARET SANDS . I keep the lodging-house—the prisoner lodged there that night—it was the first night—I met him between one and two o'clock on the first landing—I told him to wait a minute while I went to see if all was right—I missed the coat off the bed—I followed him into the mews and took him.

JOHN POWELL . I came borne from Covent Garden-market at a quarter-past one o'clock. I heard Mrs. Sands exclaim, "The old man's coat is gone on that man's back"—I followed the prisoner to Clark's-mews, and asked how he came to take the coat—he said he did not care—I took him to the station-house—he had the coat on.
Prisoner. It was distress made me do it.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

743.
MARY ANN WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of January, 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
William Spencer.

GEOROB GEE . I am in the service of Mr. William Spencer, a general salesman, in Whitechapel-road. Between three and four o'clock, on the 17th of January, these boots were outside, the door—I saw, the prisoner take them—she dropped them as soon as she saw me come outside the door—they dropped between her and another girl, who was in company with her—the other girl said, "Oh, Sall, what a fool you are!"

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You heard that quite well? A. Yes, they were passing the door—neither of them came into the shop—there were a great many boots hanging outside—I was cleaning the window, but some clothes hung before me—I saw it was the prisoner who
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged-18.—
Confined Six Months.

744.
JOHN PITMAN and
JOHN JOHNSTON were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January, I tea-caddy, value 5s., the goods of
William Trinder; and that Pitman had before been convicted of felony.
GEORGE ANTHONY . I am a writer—on the 11th of January I saw the two prisoners together, about eleven o'clock in the morning, in Whitcombe-street—I

watched them for about five minutes, and about half-past one o'clock I met them in Grafton-street—I then saw that Johnston had got Pitman's apron with something in it—I followed him to the private door of Mr. Wadmore, a pawnbroker (Pitman was on the other side of the way)—I went in at the shop door, and told the shopkeeper—he produced this caddy to me—I said, "That has been stolen; detain it and the party"—I got a policeman and sent him to the shop—I followed Pitman down Tottenham Court-road, where he was taken.
HENRY KILSSY . I live in Tottenham Court-road—I am a pawnbroker—Johnston offered me this caddy—the witness told me to detain him.
WILLIAM TRINDER . I live in Whitcombe-street—this is my caddy, and was on a table in my shop, which is open-fronted.
Pitman. It was outside instead of in.
Johnston's Defence. We were out of work, and forced to sleep in the street two nights before this, and seeing this outside we were tempted to take it—we had nothing to eat.
WILLIAM LANE . I am a policeman. I have a certificate of Pitman's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read—) I was at the trial—he is the man.

PITMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Transported for Seven Years.

JOHNSTON—
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Months.

745.
MARY BARRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 2 lbs. 2 oz. of bacon, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Loveridge.

JOHN HXATHWAITE . I am shopman to John Loveridge, a cheese
monger in Crawford-street. On the 6th of February, at half-past eleven o'clock, I was in the shop—the prisoner came and stood about the shop—I asked what she wanted—she said, "A pennyworth of bacon"—I then missed this piece, and saw it in her apron, where I also found this other piece.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Fourteen Days.

746.
JOSHUA LAKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of January, 2 saws, value 6s., the goods of William Unwin; and I saw, value 3s., the goods of
John Maynard.

WILLIAM UNWIN . I am a carpenter, and was at work on the 12th of January, at a house which was finishing at Kentish Town—I left my tools there, between twelve and one o'clock—the lock was not on, but I put a piece of wood behind the door as I went out—I suppose the person mast have got in by the kitchen area, and come out by the front door—I lost two saws—these are them—the prisoner had worked there, but was dis
charged before Christmas.
JOHN MAYNARD . I was at work at the house—I left my tools there, and lost one saw—this is it.
THOMAS DURRENT . I am a pawnbroker at Hoxton—I took in two saws of the prisoner, in the name of John Lake.
WILLIAM GEOROE STEWART . I am a pawnbroker in Kingsland-road—I took in one saw, in the name of John Lake—I cannot say of whom.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress—I took them, but meant to get them out.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

747.
WILLIAM ALFRED INGLIS and
FREDERICK JEWELL were
indicted for stealing, on the 29th of January, 1 pair of trowsers, value 12s., the goods of
James Ashman and another

JOHN WARREN . I live with Mr. James Ashman and Son, pawnbrokers, in Long-acre. On the 29th of January, the prisoner Inglis came and asked for Mercer-street—he had not been gone two minutes before I saw him and Jewell looking in at the window close to the goods—Inglis came in again—he saw the shopman, and ran out, and in about half an hour I muted a pair of trowsers—these are them.

WILLIAM HOWARD . I am a policeman. About two o'clock, on the 29th of January, Warren described the prisoners to me—I saw them looking into another shop, and took them—Jewell said, "You can search me, I have nothing about me"—on Inglis I found 7s., and on Jewell a large knife, and 3d.—they were remanded till the following day, and then Inglis told me where I could find the trowsers and he took me to No. 88, Monmouth-street, to a cellar—I found a girl—she called her mother, who said she had bought them for 2t., that they had been seated, and she had sold them for 3s., but she would get them if I would let her—she then went out with the girl, who came back with the trowsers, and said her mother was ill, but she had sent her on, not to keep me waiting—the woman did not appear before the magistrate and the girl said her mother was taken ill with the fright of my going, and was compelled to go to the Lying-in Hospital.

MARY DEVANNY . I live with my mother at No. 88, Monmouth-street. She buys and sells second-hand clothes—I was in her place when Inglis brought these trowsers, and asked half-a-crown for them—Jewell was waiting for him close by—my mother gave Inglis 2s. for them.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

INGLIS—
GUILTY . Aged 9.

JEWELL—
GUILTY . Aged 11
Whipped and discharged.

748.
HARRIET JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 9 yards of printed cotton, value 4s., the good of
John Law
rence, to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

749.
ANN MARIA WHEELER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of January, 1 cloak, value 25s.; 2 gowns, value 32s.; 1 shawl, value 10s.; 1 bonnet, value 5s.; 4 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 necklace, value 4s.; 1 slide, value 2s.; 1 brooch, value 3s., 1 ring, value 2s.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 2s.; and 1 locket, value 4s., the goods of
Lazarus Phillips, her master.

LOUISA PHILLIPS . I am the wife of Lazarus Phillips, a general dealer in the Commercial-road. The prisoner was my weekly servant—she Went away while I was out, without any notice—I missed the property stated from my first floor—it was not locked up—this is all mine—(looking at it)—and I missed several other things, which have not been found.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you not some reason to believe that somebody persuaded her to take these? A. No—I think no one would persuade her to do it—there was no other person at home but the nurse, who is still in my service.
ROBERT CAMPEN . I am a policeman. On the 26th of January, about eight o'clock at night, I was on duty in Whitechapel-road—a person came

and said he wanted to give the prisoner into custody—I said, "What for?" he said a person came and told him she had run away from her mistress, and robbed her—I took her—this cloak was on her back, these shoes on her feet, and these rings and other things in her pocket—she would not give any address or say where she slept.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY .* Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

750.
THOMAS MORTIMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of February, 4 brushes, value 1l., the goods of
William Partridge Crate.

WILLIAM PARTRIDGE CRATE . I live in East-street, Mary-le-bone, and am an oilman. On the 2nd of February the prisoner walked deliberately into my shop, unhooked these brushes from a nail, and walked out—I followed him about forty yards, and called "Stop thief"—I did not lose sight of him till he was stopped—he dropped them.
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court—I was in want, or I should not have come here.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Weeks.

751.
ELIZABETH EDWARDS and
ELIZA EDWARDS were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 25th of January, 15 yards of ribbon, value 20s., the goods of
Thomas Bird and another.

JOSEPH JEFFERSON EDWARDS . I am shopman to Thomas Bird and an
other, haberdashers, in Commercial-road. On the 25th of January, between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoners came in together, and asked to look at some bonnet-ribbon—I showed them the drawer of rib
bons—Elizabeth proposed to buy them—while she was looking at them, I saw Eliza concealing something under her cloak—they shortly after said we had no ribbon to suit them, and went out—I immediately missed the ribbon produced—they had but just got outside the door—I brought them back, and said they had taken a piece of green satin ribbon—Eliza said, "Search me," and began pulling off her cloak, and in the mean time this piece of ribbon fell—she said it fell from the counter, but I saw it fall from her person.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you standing when you brought them into the shop? A. By the side of them—I have al
ways been confident that I saw the ribbon fall from under Eliza's cloak.

WILLIAM SAWYER (police-constable K 24.) I was sent for, and took the prisoners to the station-house—while there Eliza pointed to her finger, and said, "I will give you this ring if you will endeavour to impress on the mind of the young man that the ribbon fell from the counter." ELIZA EDWARDS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months. ELIZABETH EDWARDS—
NOT GUILTY .

752.
GEORGE WEBSTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of January, 21/4|lbs. weight of coffee, value 2s., the goods of the
St. Katherine's dock Company.

THOMAS SLATER . I live in Brown Bear-alley, East Smithfield, and am a labourer at St. Katherine's-docks. On Friday, the 25th of January, the lunch-bell rang at twelve o'clock—the prisoner then came on the sixth

floor at the B warehouse—he went to a place where there were some bales of cotton, and I saw him take some coffee out of his pocket, and put it into that place—he then went to one of the bags of coffee, and took out a good many handfuls—I went to him, and said, "You are pocketing that coffee"—he said nothing, but what he had in his hand he threw down—I informed the foreman, and he followed the prisoner—I produce the coffee that was behind the cotton bales—the mark on the coffee-bag was L in a diamond.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you ever tell any body that he took many handfuls? A. Yet, I stated it before the Magistrate—I said "several handfuls."

SAMUEL BASTJER . I am foreman of the B warehouse in the St. Kathe
rine's-docks—Slater made a communication to me—I ran to the staircase, and saw the prisoner going down stairs and along the quay—Mr. Mott was in his warehouse—I beckoned him to come out—we both followed the prisoner, and stopped him just inside the door of the general dock—I knew the coffee that was in the bag—it was of the same quality as that produced from the prisoner's person—I saw what was behind the bale of cotton—that was of a different quality—we had a great many qualities in the warehouse.

THOMAS MOTT . I am warehouse-keeper of the B warehouse. I followed and came up with the prisoner—I felt his pocket, and told him I thought he had got coffee—he said he had got a little—I asked what—he was going to do with it—he said, "To take it home"—I took him back to the Custom-house office—he had no business in the B warehouse—I told Mr. Baxter he had got coffee in his pockets—he pulled out about two handfuls and a half, and said that was all he had got—Kerr then came in and took coffee from several of his pockets besides—he said he did not think there was any harm in taking a little coffee—there was 21/4 lbs. weight of it.
JAMES KERR . I am a watchman at the docks. I took this coffee from the prisoner's pockets—this is a sample from the bag—they are both alike.

(The prisoner received an excellent character.)
GUILTY . Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

753.
WILLIAM REED was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Ja
nuary, 2 shirts, value 1l. 2s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of
Charles Birch, his master.

CHARLES BIRCH . I live in Vere-street, Oxford-street, and am a linen
draper. The prisoner had been six months in my service—these shirts and other articles were brought to me by the witness—they are mine—I was not aware of the robbery, till they were brought to me—I lost these and a great many more articles.

WILLIAM MITCHELL . I am a policeman. I went to Driscoll, who was charged as a receiver, but the bill was thrown out—I found this property there—I went and took the prisoner—I told him it was for stealing some shirts and other property from Mr. Birch—he said, "Yes," and asked me if I had found all the property—this is the property I found.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months

754.
GEORGE YOUNG was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Ja
nuary, 1 coat, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Sarah Avila.

JAMES IIAMMETT . I am in the service of Mrs. Sarah Avila, she is a widow, and keeps a pawnbroker's shop in Mile End-road. On the 16th of January I saw the prisoner come into the shop, take this coat off the shelf, and run off with it—I followed, and took him—he threw it down.
Prisoner. I was in great distress.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Six Months.

755.
GEORGE GOULD was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Ja
nuary, 2 pewter pots, value 2s., the goods of
James Alehouse.

FRANCIS FRYER . I am a police-sergeant. I fell in with the prisoner on the 30th of January in Tottenham Court-road, carrying a bag with two pint pots—I asked him what he had got there—he said, "I am sorry to say they are pots"—I took him, and found the owner of them.

JAMES ALEHOUSE . I keep a public-house in King-street, Camden Town. These are my pots, and I have lost twelve dozen within the last eight months—I cannot say that I had seen the prisoner in my house or near there.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

p.hi: Third Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
756.
JOHN BUCK was indicted
for embezzling, on the 4th of Febru
ary, 2s. 6d., which he had received on account of
John Hone, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

757.
SAMUEL BRADLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 650 pamphlets, value 1l. 2s., the goods of
William James Stych; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

758.
STEPHEN JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of feb
ruary, 20 nails, value 1s., the goods of
Walker Wood and others, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

759.
JOHN PARKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Febru
ary, 10lbs. weight of iron, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Silk, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Weeks.

760.
JOHN PARKER was again indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 1 plane, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Wills.
THOMAS WILLS . I am a journeyman coach-maker, and live in Crown-court, Bow-street—this is my plane—(looking at it)——it was found at the prisoner's premises—I had not missed it.
JOHN HOLLAND . I am a coach-smith. I went with an officer to the prisoner's lodging, and found the plane in a drawer there—the prisoner works in the same employ as Wills.
Prisoner's Defence. My wife's mother asked me to put a bottom on a chair for her, as she had some pieces of wood—I went to ask Wills to lend

me his plane—he was not there, and I took the liberty of taking it, intend
ing to put it back in its place. Witness, I found some pieces of wood at his lodging, and his wife said he was going to make a chair-bottom with it.
NOT GUILTY .

761.
EDWARD WILKINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 106 yards of canvas, value 2l. 17s., the goods of
James Higgs and another.

FREDERICK WILLIAM HANKS . I am shopman to James and Thomas Higgs, of Wentworth-place, Mile-end-road. On the afternoon of the 6th of February, a man applied to be served with ribbon; and while serving him, I saw the prisoner in the act of drawing a piece of canvas out of the shop, from about two yards and a half inside the door—he had got it four or five yards from the door, and was walking away from the shop—when I came up, he said, "I believe this belongs to you, sir," and pat it from his shoulder—I took the goods, and let him go, but kept my eye on him till I saw a policeman, and he was brought back in a short time—I am certain he is the man that took the canvas.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you ever seen him before that evening? A. No—his back was turned to me when he was going away with it—I am quite sure of him.

WILLIAM HAOOERTT (police-constable K 55.) Hanks told me to stop the prisoner—I saw him in Cleveland-street, about twenty yards from the shop—when he saw me after him he ran away, and I lost sight of him—when I caught hold of him he was flurried, and could scarcely speak—I took him back.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it not a man like the prisoner yon first saw walking away? A. Yes—he afterwards returned towards me, from a dark place, where I had lost sight of him, and I caught hold of him—he appeared to me to be sober—he gave his right name and address at the station-house.
COURT. Q. Have you such a recollection of the man as to say it was the prisoner? A. I cannot say—he was between me and the lamp when he ran away—Mr. Higgs identified him.

THOMAS HIGGS . I am in partnership with James Higgs. I was in the shop on the day in question—my young man ran to the door—I imme
diately followed him, and he had got the canvas from the prisoner's shoul
der—he was between twenty and thirty yards from me—I pursued, and never lost sight of him till I stopped him—the policeman came up directly, and I gave charge of him—I am certain he is the man Hanks pointed out to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not the prisoner's back turned to you when you first saw him? A. It was—I took him in rather a dark place—when be got there he turned round, and faced me—I was not more than six or seven yards from him then.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

762.
JAMES LIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of February, 12 shovels, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas Kenning and another.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS (City police-constable, No. 32.) On the evening of the 7th of February, I was on duty in Lime-street, and met the prisoner, about half-past six o'clock, with a bundle of shovels on his back, in com
pany
with another lad—I went up to him, and his companion whistled—the prisoner then threw the shovels down, and ran away—I followed, and he was stopped without my losing sight of him.

JOHN THOMPSON . I am in the employ of Thomas Kenning and William Chapman, of Philpot-lane and Birmingham. I missed two dozen shovels from their stock—I am certain these are our property—(looking at them.)

Cross-examined by MR. PHILIPS. Q. Were you always certain of them? A. Yes—I do not believe I have said I believed them to be ours—(The witness's deposition being read, stated, "I believe them to be part of those stolen")—the person who wrote that should have put it in a different form—he read it over to me—I was certain of them before the Magistrate—all shovels that come from Birmingham are done up in the same way—we had twelve dozen looked up for an order—I know them by this mark on two, "J. L. & Co.," meaning "John Linden & Co."—they are extensive manufacturers at Birmingham—there was a tally on them when taken, si
milar to what I have here.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three
Months.

763.
THOMAS DOWNS,
THOMAS WAKEFIELD , and
WIL
LIAM WALLER were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February, 1 metal cock, value 2s. 9d.; the goods of
Philip Stock.

JOHN WARD . I am a publican, and live in Gray's Inn-lane. On the morning of the 8th of February I was in Mr. Stock's shop, and heard a noise, as if glass was breaking—I waited, and ten minutes after I saw a dirty hand come through the window, and take out a metal cock, through the broken pane—I rushed out and caught the three prisoners in my arms, standing as near together as possible—I looked over them, and saw the cock in one of their hands, I do not know which—Downs bobbed his head, and got a short distance from me, and I saw him throw the cock down—I let the others go, and followed Downs?—I saw Mr. Stock coming towards me—I then ceased to follow Downs, and followed the other two, and secured them both, without losing sight of them hardly a moment—I am certain they are the three—I had watched them for two hours previous to the robbery, Mr. Stock having lost two cocks that morning—and I had seen the three prisoners about his window six times that morning—Mr. Stock lives next door to me.

PHILIP STOCK . I live in Gray's Inn-lane. I was in Gray's Inn-lane, and SAW the prisoners three or four times, walking backwards and forwards, and looking at my window—I saw Wakefield put his hand in through the broken pane, but he did not get any thing out—I went to the corner of Gray's Inn
gate, and had a full view of them there—I saw them all walk back—one of the little ones put his hand in, and then they walked off—Ward rushed out of my shop, and I went to his assistance—this cock is my property.
JOHN BULLOCK (police-constable G 116.) I heard the cry of "Stop thief," and stopped Wakefield, and Maddocks stopped Waller—I took them to Ward, and Downs was given into my custody.
GEORGE MADDOCKS . I am a policeman. I stopped Waller, who was running away from the shop in company with Wakefield—the prosecutor was calling "Stop thief"—it was about eleven o'clock.

Waller's Defence. I and Wakefield were coming along and met this boy—a man caught hold of him—Wakefield ran after me, and two po
licemen stopped us.
(Downs received a good character.)

DOWNS—
GUILTY . Aged 13.

WAKEFIELD—
GUILTY . Aged 17. WALLER—
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Three Months.

764.
THOMAS PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of February, 2 yards of woollen cloth, value 1l. 5s.; the goods of
Robert Woollams.

ROBERT WOOLLAMS . I am a tailor, and live in Union-street, Spital
fields. On the evening of the 5th of February I left ray shop, and went to the back-parlour—I was alarmed, returned, and missed a piece of cloth from my counter—I ran to the door and saw the prisoner about fifty yards off, running very fast, in the middle of the road, with a bundle under his arm—I followed, overtook him, unbuttoned his coat, and took the cloth from under his coat—this is it—(looking at it)—I had seen it just before.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure he had the cloth? A. Yes—I know it by being cut in a particular manner.
JANE FLOWER . I was in the prosecutor's shop, and saw a boy enter it, and snatch the cloth up—I alarmed the prosecutor.

THOMAS BURCHAM . I am a policeman. I received the prisoner in cus
tody, and took charge of the property.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

765.
HARRIET HUMPHRIES was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of February, 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s.; 1 printed book, value 6d.;1 cap, value 7s.; and 1 blind, value 1s.; the goods of
William Hunsdon, her master.

ANN HUNSDON . I am the wife of William Hunsdon, and live in Falcon-square—the prisoner was our charwoman. On the 7th of February, at two o'clock, I observed something very white hanging below her dress, and having missed a great many things, I took up her dress, and found one of my sheets under it—I gave her into custody, and afterwards went to her lodging with an officer—I there found a holland blind, a petticoat, a pair of boots, and four caps, all belonging to us—these are them—(took
ing at them.)
RICHARD SAVAGE (City police-constable, No. 56.) I went with the prosecutrix to the lodging pointed out by the prisoner, in Alfred-place, Ball's-alley, and found these articles.
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

766.
THOMAS HOLLIDAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of January, 3 bottles, value 6d.; and 2 regulators, value 8s.; the goods of
William Harper, his master.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) On the morning of the 29th of January, about a quarter past seven o'clock, I apprehended the prisoner in Broad-street, St. Giles's—he said he lived in Red Lion-street, Holborn, and then at No. 26, Bedford-street—I wont to Bedford-street,

and found he lived there—I there found three copper water-bottles and two regulators, in a basket in a cupboard, covered with some rubbish, in the two-pair of stairs room—I found his wife there with his children.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did not he tell you exactly in what part of the house he lived? A. No, I have no recollection of it—I am quite sure he did not say it was the two-pair of stairs—(looking at his deposition)—this is my hand-writing—it was read over to me—(The depo
sition being ready stated, "He said it was on the two-pair of stairs")—I do not recollect his saying so—I am certain I told the Magistrate the truth—I have no doubt the prisoner did tell me so.

DOROTHY HARPER . I am a widow, and keep a house in Bedford-street, Red Lion-square—the prisoner and his wife lodged with me on the second floor—I saw the room the officer searched—it was the room the prisoner occupied.

WILLIAM HARPER . I am a stove manufacturer, and live in King Wil
liam-street. The prisoner came into my service nearly four months back—I discharged him on the 26th of January—the articles produced are mine—they are worth 10s.—he had no authority to remove them from the premises.

Cross-examined. Q. You have a great quantity of these things? A. Yes—I had things similar to these made for a patent stove—Wright and Nash, of Oxford-street, purchase of me, and may have the same things—I have no partner—Mr. Joyce has not been in partnership with me since May—I did not discharge the prisoner for fraud.
GEORGE HULLS . I am a coppersmith, and live in Union-street. These articles were made in my factory, for Mr. Harper.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you made for any other firm? A. No. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.

777.
JOSEPH EARL was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of February, 3lbs. 15oz. weight of bacon, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Frederick Pamphilon.

THOMAS SGUTCHEY . I am shopman to Frederick Pamphilon, of Oxford-street. On the night of the 8th of February I saw the prisoner take a piece of bacon from inside the window, and run off with it—I ran after him, and brought him back with it—I said, "Where did you get this?"—he said, "What have I got to pay?"—I said, "I do not do business so; you must come back."

RICHARD BOURKE . I am a policeman. I was sent for to the prosecutor's, and found the prisoner with the bacon—I found a sovereign and a half
sovereign, one shilling, a halfpenny, and a knife, on him. (Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. The money I had belonged to my employer.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

778.
FRANCOISE TATON
was indicted for stealing, on the 30th of January, 1 watch, value 1l. 5s.; 1 watch ribbon, value 1d.; and 1 watch key, value 1d.; the goods of
Jacques Haas, in a vessel, in a port of entry and discharge; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

779.
JOHN SIDFORD was indicted
for a misdemeanor; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

780.
JOHN TILLETT was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of Janu
ary, 1 cloak, value 20s., the goods of
Theodore Tillett: and
ALEXANDER EBBS
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.; to which

TILLETT pleaded
GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Three Months., THEODORE TILLETT. I am a widow. The prisoner Tillett it my son—I missed a cloth cloak from a box in my room, in Mark-street, Finsbury, a month ago next Friday—my son came that night, and I gave him into cus
tody

MATTHEW PEAK . I am a policeman. I took Tillett into custody, and in consequence of what he told me I went with Brannan to No. 6, Old Cock-lane, Shoreditch, and found Ebbs—I said, "Do you know any thing about the cloak?"—he said, "No, I know nothing about it"—I went to
wards a closet by the fire-place, and Brannan went towards at chest of drawers—Ebbs followed him, and said ht had got the cloak—I then, saw the cloak in Brannan's hands.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he not say, "Oh, yes, there is a cloak," before Brannan found it? A. I cannot say, because I was look
ing into the cupboard—Brannan was going towards the drawer before he said any thing about having it.

JAMES BRANNAN . I am a policeman. On Saturday, the 19th of Janu
ary, I went with Peak to Ebbs's lodging—Peak asked him about the cloak—he said, "I know nothing of a cloak; I have no cloak here"—I west towards a chest of drawers—the prisoner followed me, and opened the drawers—I put my hand upon the cloak, and he did so at the same time, and said, "Oh, ah, here is a cloak"—I said, "How did you get it?"—he said he lent a boy 4s. on it, to get his things out of pawn.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you understand whether that boy was Tillett? A. I did not—I have since heard that it was not—I have been looking for one Lenton, but cannot find him—I believe Ebbs is a willow-weaver—I
found no other stolen property on his premises.

EBBS—
NOT GUILTY .

781.
JOHN BROAD was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of January, 150lbs. weight of lead, value 2l., the goods of
Eliza Parry, being fixed to a certain building; against the Statute, &c.: and
JOHN HOLTON
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

CHARLES DAVIES . I am coachman in the service of Mrs. Eliza Parry, of Lower Brook-street. On the 31st of January I noticed the roof of the stable in Cock-yard, Davis-street, and perceived lead deficient—I after
wards missed more lead, altogether about 11/2 cwt—I have not seen any part of it since.

HENRY MOTT . I live with my father, who is a poulterer, in Thomas-street, Grosvenor-square. On Thursday, the 31st of January, about eight o'clock in the evening, I met the witness Pemberton in Tom's-court, with a sack on his head—the prisoner Broad told me that he was going to get lead—they both went into Holton's shop with it, in Tom's-court, with Pember
ton—they were there about ten minutes—they then came out together, and went along Duke-street—I knew Broad before, we went to school together—I did not see him that day before I saw him with Pemberton in Tom's-court, nor after—he did not tell me where he was going to get the lead—he
had spoken to me in Brook-street, about six o'clock, and told me he was going to get the lead—he did not say where.

JOSEPH PEMBERTON (a prisoner.)I have been an errand-boy, and lodged with my mother, in East-street, Manchester-square. I have known Broad a little while—I bare only seen Holton twice or three times at most—he lives in Tom's-court, Thomas-street, Oxford-street—I know a per
son named El wood. On Wednesday week, the 30th of January, between six and seven o'clock, Broad and El wood came to my house, and wanted me to come to Gilbert-street, Oxford-street, to get some lead—Mrs. Parry's stables are at the back of Gilbert-street—we went to the stable in Cock-yard—Elwood and Broad lifted me up on the wall—I had no knife—I pulled the lead off with my hands, and chucked it down, and gave it to Elwood and Broad—there were two pieces—Elwood took the lead into the mews, left it there, and went and borrowed a sack of Holton—I got down from the wall into Gilbert-street, and went with Elwood into Holton's shop, with a piece of lead, for which he received 4s.—he was to receive As. 3d., but the 3d. was not paid—Holton put the lead underneath the counter—this was between six and seven o'clock—I afterwards met Broad in Duke-street, and he told me he had got 3s. 6d. for the other piece of lead—Elwood gave me half-a-crown—I did not see Mott at all that night—we went again the following night, and that night I saw him in Tom's-court—Broad was with me—Mott saw us together—nothing was said when we took the lead into Holton's the night before—Broad produced the lead—Holton said nothing, but put it into the scale and weighed it—he did not say what it weighed, but said it came to 7s. 3d. the two pieces—both the pieces were there—Broad took one, and Elwood the other, into the shop—when I went in with Elwood, his piece came to 4s. 3d.—Holton paid him 4s.—I was not there when Broad took in the second piece—I did not hear Holton say it came to 7s. 3d., but that was what it did come to—he asked no questions where it came from, but put it into the scale.

Cross-examined. Q. Why did you say at first he put it under the counter, instead of into the scales? A. So he did put it under the coun
ter—he weighed it—J did not think of that at first—I had no notion that they wanted to steal the lead till I got there—they would not let me go home—they hoisted me on the wall—I went up, not quite willingly—I could not help going up—he gave me the 2s. 6d.—he said I had better have my share of it—he pressed me to take it—I have just come out of Newgate now—I have been in Newgate before, that is about six months ago—I have been in this Court before, for stealing two straw bonnets—I was in Newgate a week after that, and then at the House of Correction for three months.

SAMUIL LOFTING . I am employed at Mr. Mivart's stables, in Cock-yard, Davis-street. I took Pemberton into custody there on the landing
place—I know nothing of this transaction.

EDWARD PIGGOTT . I received charge of Pemberton in Gilbert-street, on the 1st of February, between 11 and 12 o'clock, and in consequence of information, I went to the Three Compasses in Silver-street, and found Broad—I told him I took him for stealing lead in company with Pember
ton, in Cock-yard—he said it was not him, but Pemberton—I went next day to Holton's shop, in Tom's-court, but found no lead.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you saw Holton? A. Yes, he went with me to the police-office.

WILLIAM ONSBY . I live with my mother, in Tom's-court. On Thurs
day, the 31st of January, I saw Pemberton with a load on his head—he could scarcely walk—Broad was with him—they went to Holton's shop—I knew Broad before, I used to go to school with him.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not Holton's name there over his door? A. Yes, they staid in the shop about a quarter of an hour.
NOT GUILTY .

782.
JAMES RICHARDSON was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM TAMSETT . I live in High-street, St. Giles's. The prisoner was in my service between three and four months, to go on errands, and boarded and lodged with me—on the 18th of January, I sent him to my brother-in-law to receive 2l. 10s., and gave him a note—it was sealed—he returned about half-past twelve o'clock, saying, my brother was out, and he could not get the money till the morning—I sent him again in the morn
ing, and he did not return—he was in the habit of going backwards and forwards between my brother and me, bringing money.

HENRY NEWNHAM . I am a baker, and live in King-street, Tower-hill The prisoner brought me this note from my brother-in-law—I gave him two sovereigns and a half—I did not tell him what he was to do with it—he was in the habit of coming from my brother for money—I told him to be careful and not lose it
JOHN FRYER (police-constable E 118.) I apprehended the prisoner in St. Giles's, on the 22nd of January.
(The note being read, requested that 2l. 10s. should be sent.)

Prisoners Defence. I had the parcel given to me, and had the misfor
tune to lose it.
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(The prosecutor stated that he had lost 9l. in a fortnight by the prisoner.)

783.
THOMAS WINTER ,
GEORGE TURNER, alias George Body,
and
WILLIAM CLARKE , were indicted for
stealing on the 12th of Ja
nuary, 31/2lbs. of pork, value 2s. 4d. the goods of
Thomas Johnson; and that Clarke had been previously convicted of felony.

CHARLES TURNER . I am in the service of Thomas Johnson, a butcher, in Hackney-road. On Saturday, the 12th of January, about nine o'clock in the evening, Kemp the officer came to the shop, and in consequence of what he said, I looked outside the shop, and missed two pieces of pork, which I had seen safe two minutes before.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty in the Hackney-road, on the evening of the 12th of January, and a little before nine o'clock the three prisoners passed me—I knew them before, and watched them for about twenty minutes—I saw them all three pass Johnson's shop—Turner turned back and took two pieces of pork out of a dish in front of the shop, and gave it to Clarke, who gave it to Winter—I crossed the road directly and took Winter—as I crossed the road he said to Clarke, "D—your eyes, go back and get some more"—I took Winter to the station-house with the pork—I took him on Monday to the office—I saw Clarke and Turner waiting outside there, and secured them.
Turner's Defence. I was at home and in bed at the time he says he

saw me—I was standing about Spitalfields market, where I get my living by portering, on the Monday, and followed the mob to the office, seeing two lads whose faces I knew—I just went in to look at them, and was taken for this robbery, of which I know nothing.

Clarke's Defence. On the Monday after the robbery I was passing through Worship-street, when the policeman took hold of me, and charged me with this robbery—I know nothing of it—I was at home and at work at the time.

DENNIS POWER (police-constable H 18.) I was a witness against a person named George Clarke, who was tried here in April last year—the prisoner Clarke is that person—I am sure of it—I have a certificate of his conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read.)

Clarke. It must be a mistake, I was never here before. Witness. I am sure he is the person—I apprehended him myself at his mother's door—it was for stealing five pairs of clogs—he was tried in the New Court, and got six months' imprisonment—I heard him sentenced—I have not the smallest doubt he is the person—his mother is now outside, and she has been talking to me about it this morning.

WINTER*—
GUILTY . Aged 15. TURNER*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined Three Months. CLARKE*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

784.
WILLIAM ABRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of feb
ruary, 2 gallons of gin, value 1l. 1s., and 1 pint of rum, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Richard Moss, his master.

RICHARD MOSS . I keep the Adam and Eve, in St. John-street-road—the prisoner lived with me about nine days. On the 7th of February, after I was gone to bed, I heard a noise in the house—I went down, and called out "Hollo"—he made no answer—at last he said, "It's me"—I said, "Who is me?"—he said, "William"—he said he was ill—he was in the scullery—I kicked my foot against a bottle of gin, and asked what it was—he said water—I asked what he was going to do with it—he said he did not know—I found both the windows of the bar unfastened, which I had fastened before I went to bed—he had got in at one window just under a door, and opened the door—I brought the gin away, called in a policeman, and he shewed us the tub he took the gin out of—I found a bottle of rum in the kitchen, and a funnel wrapped up in one of the children's dresses—he had broken the window by falling down, and that disturbed me.
FREDERICK CHAPPELL (police-constable G 221.) I apprehended the prisoner, and have the gin. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

785.
MARY JANE FRANCES BINKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 1 shawl, value 3s., the goods of
Edward De Lima Woods.

EDWARD DE LIMA WOODS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in King-street, Hammersmith. On the 30th of January, I hung this shawl up in my shop, but did not miss it till the 31st—the prisoner was a customer at my shop.
HENRY BRITTAIN . I am shopman to Mr. Watts, a pawnbroker, at
Hammersmith. I have a shawl pawned on the 30th of January by the prisoner, for 2s., in the name of Eliza Williams, No. 4, King-street—I knew her before—she had been a customer a long time.

(Property produced and sworn to.) GEORGE LOWE. I apprehended the prisoner at Mr. Aldous', a pawn
broker, at Hammersmith.
Prisoner. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court—it is my first
offence—I was driven to it from distress.
GUILTY . Aged 18.—Strongly recommended to mercy.
Confined Fourteen Days.

786.
JOHN VENDOME was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Feb
ruary, 1 pair of trowsers, value 155., the goods of William Nathan.

BENJAMIN LINO . I am shopman to William Nathan, a pawnbroker, in Three Colt-street, Limehouse. I missed a pair of trowsers from the door, and went to Ratcliff-highway—I saw the prisoner in company with two other persons—the prisoner separated from them—I followed him till I met an officer, and then gave him in charge—he was searched at the sta
tion-house, and the trowsers found secreted under his coat, round his body—he said he bought them in Rosemary-lane—I had seen them sale at two o'clock.

LOWTHER JACKSON . I am a tailor, and live in Three Colt-street On the 7th of February, about six o'clock, I saw the prisoner with two others pass my door—the prisoner looked into my shop—I went to the door, and they got to Nathan's, which is two doors from me—I went in-doors, and sent my son to inform Mr. Nathan that suspicious characters were at his door, and when I got back to the door they were gone—they were fol
lowed, and the prisoner was taken,
THOMAS SQUIRE . I am a policeman. I took him into custody and found the trowsers concealed under his jacket.

(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
787.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for an indecent assault.
NOT GUILTY .

788.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was again indicted
for a like offence.
NOT GUILTY .

789.
JAMES HURLEY was indicted
for forging a request for the delivery of 5000 of twenty-penny clasp nails, and 6000 ten-penny clasp nails, with intent to defraud
Samuel Bradney.

RICHARD BODDINOTON . I am shopman to Samuel Bradney, an iron
monger. About half-past three o'clock on Friday, the 1st of February, Mr. Bradney brought this order to me in the warehouse, and in conse
quence of what he said to me, I went into the shop and saw the prisoner—I had the order in my hand—I asked him if he wanted to take the nails with him—he said he would—this is the order—(read)—"Please let the bearer have 5000 twenty-penny clasp nails, and 5000 ten-penny ditto, put them in a bag. For William Brooks, builder, No. 1, Fourawl-court; Rosemary-lane"—Mr. Brooks deals with Mr. Bradney—I did not give the

prisoner the nails—we suspected the order was not correct, and I went up to Mr. Brooks and asked him if it was his order—I asked the prisoner where he was to take the nails to—he said to a public-house (I forget the name of it) in Osborne-street—I asked if they were to be used there—he did not answer me directly, but after a bit he said they were not to be used there, but there was a man waiting there for them.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did he not tell you he was to take them to the Three Compasses, in Brick-lane? A. Yes, he said the man would be there who had sent him with the order.

WILLIAM BROOKS . I am a builder, and live in Ables-buildings, Rose
mary-lane. I deal with Mr. Bradney—I do not know the prisoner to my knowledge—I may have seen him—this order is not my writing—it is a forgery.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it the handwriting of any body in your estab
lishment? A. No, nobody wrote it by my direction.
WILLIAM BROOKS, JUN . I am a son of the last witness. This order is not my writing—I did not authorize the prisoner to take it—I know nothing about it.
SAMUEL BRADNEY . On Friday afternoon, about half-past three o'clock, the prisoner came to my shop and presented this order to me—I made inquiry, and afterwards took him into custody.
JURY. Q. On his stating he was to carry these nails to a public-house, did you go there to make inquiry? A. I did not.
NOT GUILTY .

790.
SAMUEL HARVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of February, I dead fowl, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Morris.

JAMES MORRIS . I am a poulterer and cheesemonger, and live in Church-street, Hackney. On the 2nd of February, in consequence of information from the witness Ogan, I looked at the poultry that was exposed for sale, and missed a fowl—I went with Ogan to the Old Mer
maid—he there pointed out the prisoner to me, and told me his name, and said, "That is the person that stole the fowl"—I said, "Come, Mr. Harvey, give me the fowl, let us have no bother about it, all I want is my fowl"—he denied all knowledge of it—I saw a fowl afterwards taken out from between some water-butts.
Prisoner. Q. Will you swear it was your fowl? A. I will not swear to it, but I believe it to be mine.

WILLIAM HENRY OGAN . I am a shoemaker, and live in Church-street, Hackney. I was standing at my father's door on Saturday evening, the 2nd of February, directly opposite the prosecutor's—I saw the prisoner pass with three others, and as he passed, he took a fowl from the prose
cutor's window, passed it along to the other three, and turned up the old Mermaid-yard, which is close by—I immediately ran and informed the prosecutor, told him the prisoner's name, and went with him into the Mermaid public-house, where I found the prisoner, with others, in the parlour—the water-butts, where the for was taken from, are up the yard, a little distance from the door—the prisoner would have an opportunity of putting it there before he went into the house.
THOMAS OAKES . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody at the Mermaid, and found the fowl between two water-butts in the back yard.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been at work for two days, at Isle worth, and had been with three others to take our money on this day—we went into the Mermaid to meet my wife, and directly we sat down, the policeman came and took me—the prosecutor said if he only had his fowl, he would say nothing more about it—if I had been guilty, I should have told him of it without being locked up.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

791.
CHARLES GONIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Ja
nuary, 2 chairs, value 10s., the goods of
John Knight Aston.

CHARLOTTE HANNAH ASTON . I am the wife of John Knight Aston, of Goodge-street, Tottenham Court-road. On the 28th of January, about six o'clock in the evening, I missed two chairs, which I had seen safe at four o'clock—I have seen the prisoner repeatedly about our house.

WILLIAM LOVEOEOVE STKES . I am a broker, and live in Earl-street, Seven-dials. I have had dealings with the prisoner several times. On Monday evening, the 28th of January, I bought these two chairs of him.
GEORGE JOHN RBSTIBAUX . lam a policeman. I took possession of the chairs, made search after the prisoner, and took him. (Property produced and acorn to.)
Prisoner. Distress drove me to it.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
792.
ANN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 9 hare-skins, value 8s.; and 4 rabbit-skins, value 4d.; the goods of
John Hughes; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

793.
MARIA WEAVER was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Feb
ruary, 1 sovereign, the money of
George Wills, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

794.
WILLIAM ELDRIDGE was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of January, 2 printed books, value 5s., the goods of
William Simmons; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged.—
Confined Three Months.

795.
JAMES SALTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 1 cap, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Samuel Humm; and that he had been previously convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

796.
FREDERICK LAWSON and
JOHN SPENCER HIBBS
were indicted for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Lewis Anwell (since deceased,) about two o'clock in the night of the 14th of January, at St. Mary Matfelon, alias
Whitechapel, and stealing therein 5 watches, value 10l.;17 spoons, value 15s.; 2 brooches, value 15s.; 1 watch-key, value 2s. 6d.;2 pairs of ear-rings, value 10s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; 72 pence, and 100 halfpence; the goods and monies of the said Lewis Anwell.

HARRIET ANWELL . I am the widow of Lewis Anwell. He was alive at the time of this robbery, but very ill indeed—my house is the Halfmoon and Punchbowl, in Buckle-street, in the parish of St. Mary Matfelon Whitechapel—I know the prisoners—they, with two others, named Nathan and Gardener, were at my house on the 14th of January—Lawson was em
ployed in the house as pot-boy—at one o'clock, on the morning of the 14th of January, he helped me to put the shutters up—I heard some noise in the course of the night, which alarmed me—I suppose it was about ten minutes before three o'clock—it was as if something heavy had fallen into an empty room—such a noise as a man would make in falling from a window—I came down, about eleven o'clock in the morning, and went into the bar—I found my cash-box broken open, and missed from it a gold watch, four silver watches, a quantity of spoons, a trinket-box, with rings and different things in it—the value of all I lost is about 13l.—I have since seen one of the watches, but none of the other property, except what was in the possession of Lawson's brother—I had taken nearly 200l. up stairs with me the night before, and that I had with me up stairs—I went into the long room, where there is a sky-light—I found the pulley of the sky-light drawn up, and the birch-broom put up, to keep it up—that win
dow opens by a pulley inside—by pulling a rope, the window would go up—I had left that window shut, when I went to bed, and all the house shut up—I had done it myself—Lawson went round with me—I had left that room safe at half-past one o'clock—Lawson did not sleep in the house—there is a wall and a water-butt outside the house.

HENRY BROWN . I am the prosecutrix's father. On the night before the robbery, I saw Gardener, Lawson, and Hibbs in my daugh
ter's house—I saw Lawson and Gardener in the long room, trying to pull up the sky-light by the rope—Hibbs was standing by them, and he said they should pull the other rope, and that would take the sky-light up—I saw them again on the Monday night all together, Lawson, Gardener, Nathan, and Hibbs—that was the night as the robbery was discovered in the morning—I went into the long room in the morning, and found the sky-light up, the broom under it, and the door open.

NAOMI ANWELL . I am the prosecutrix's daughter. I was the first person that opened the bar on the morning of the 15th of January—I did so at eight o'clock—I found it shut—I unlocked it, and unscrewed the shutters.

WILLIAM NORMOYLE (police-sergeant H 15.) I was called in by the pro
secutrix to examine the house, on the Tuesday morning, the 15th—I found the sky-light, in the long room, open, and the birch-broom under it, to keep it so—I also saw a small door, which leads from the long room into the bar, forced open, and a drawer in the bar forced open—it appeared to me that the entrance had been made through the sky-light, because the dust on the frame of it was rubbed off, as if a person had dropped from there into the room—it is a few yards from the floor—a person falling, or dropping from it to the floor, would necessarily make some noise—I took Hibbs into custody—he said he was innocent of it.
ALLEN PIPE (police-constable H 51.) On the night of the 17th of January I went to a house, in Craig's-court, Whitechapel, and took a young

woman into custody, and found the duplicate of a watch in the coal-hole, under the stairs—in consequence of information, I went to the lodging of George Lawson, in Kingsland-road, and got a ticket—I also found a watch-key there.

GEORGE LAWSON . I am the prisoner's brother, and lodge in Orange-street, Bethnal-green-road, and work for a floor-cloth manufacturer. One day in January, my brother produced a watch to me—I exchanged mine for it, on trial—I afterwards pawned it at Mr. Cotton's, in Hackney-road.
SAMUEL WALKER . I am in the employ of Mr. Cotton, a pawnbroker, in Hackney-road. I have a watch, which was pawned by George Lawson, on the 17th of January.

CORNELIUS FOAY (police-constable H 98.) I took Lawson into custody. I asked him if he knew Gardener—he said he did not—I said, "He was in your company at Mr. Anwell's, on the morning of the robbery"—he said he did not know him.

MART WRIGHT . I am the wife of John Wright, and lire in the same house as the prisoner Lawson. On Tuesday morning, the 15th of Ja
nuary, I saw Lawson and Gardener together, in Lawson's room—Gardener sat in the room by the fire side—I did not hear any conversation between them.

JOHN BRIGHTWELL . I am a shoemaker, and live in Buckle-square, Buckle-street. I know Nathan, Lawson, and Hibbs—I have seen them together at the prosecutrix's house—on Tuesday morning, the 15th of January, I was awoke by the top of the water-butt falling off—I looked out of window, it was rather a dark morning—I cannot tell what hour it was—(I was very poorly—I had been taking medicine, and went to bed very early that evening)—I saw three or four men—I saw three, and heard another one—I thought I heard voices, which I knew; one was Nathan's, and another Lawson's—I could not say exactly whose voices the others were—I could see three men, and heard a fourth voice—I saw Nathan, and I am almost sure I heard Lawson's voice—I saw Nathan and Hibbs on the wall—on the Saturday night before the robbery, I was in the long room, and saw Lawson, Hibbs, Nathan, and another, there—I saw Hibbs put the broom under the sky-light, to open it—I saw Hibbs take and pull a rope, and say, "This is the way"—he said so to Nathan—I had frequently seen the prisoners there before—I never saw them in my pas
sage.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know a person who goes by the name of Mad Jack? A. Not to ray knowledge—I never heard any one call me so—I do not very often go to this long room.
MRS. ANWELL re-examined. This watch is one of those which was taken out of my bar—it is mine.
Lawson. I have witnesses to prove that this man Brightwell has false-sworn himself.

LAWSON—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

HIBBS—
NOT GUILTY .

797.
WILLIAM LAKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of January, 18 pence and 37 half-pence, the monies of
Richard Strong, his master, to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

798.
HANNAH EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of January, 2 jars, value 3d.;11/2lbs. weight of jam, value 2s.; 2 towels, value 2s.; 5 sheets, value 11s.; 4 tablecloths, value 15s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 2 napkins, value 3s.; and 1 pillow-case, value 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Brittain.—Also for stealing, on the 28th of January, 1 cloak, value 20s., the goods of
John Milward, to which she pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.
(The prisoner received a good character, and was recommended to mercy.)

799.
JOHN TOPPER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of August, 1 shawl, value 6s.; and 1 pair of spectacles, value 18s., the goods of
John Plummer, his master.

SUSAN PLUMMER . I am the wife of John Plummer, a cotton manu
facturer, in Tower-street. His manufactory is in Golden-lane—the prisoner had been in our service about eight years as an engineer—we missed the shawl and spectacles.

CHARLES WOODHAM . I am in the service of Mr. Boyce, pawnbroker, in Great Charles-street, New Cut. These spectacles were taken in by a young man who has left us, and this is the duplicate of them—(looking at one.)
BENJAMIN MEECHAM . I am in the service of Mr. Walter, pawnbroker in Aldersgate-street. I produce a shawl—I cannot say who pawned it—this is the duplicate of it—(looking at one.)
EDWARD WARE (City police-constable No. 79.) I took the prisoner on the 22nd of January, and found on him fourteen duplicates, and amongst the rest, the duplicates of these things.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. They were pawned in August, were they not? A. Yes, both of them.

SUSAN PLUMMER
re-examined. These are my property—the prisoner had access to the place where they were.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

800.
JOSHUA HARWOOD was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of January, 2561bs. weight of tallow, value 7l. 10s., the goods of
Morris Parry and others, his masters: and
JOHN MARCH
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

MORRIS PARRY . I am one of the firm of Catherine Parry and Sons. We are tallow-chandlers in Fleur-de-lis-court, Spitalfields—Harwood was our errand-boy for about three months—on Friday morning, the 11th of January, our man found a sack in the cellar, which he brought up to me—it had the appearance of having had tallow in it—I desired him to put it where he found it—about five o'clock, Harwood left to go to tea—I followed, with our man—he went into the shop of the prisoner March, in Lamb-street—it is an oil-shop—I went in, and saw Harwood and March there, and the bag which I had seen before, was on the weighing-machine—Har
wood was taking the money off the counter as I went in, and March was behind the counter—the bag contained thirty-six pounds of Russia tallow—I asked Harwood what he did there—he said he came to buy soap and soda—I pointed to the bag—he then immediately began to cry, and begged I would forgive him, as his father had died that morning, and he did it to buy a coffin—I told March I was surprised he should buy tallow of such a boy
