it was part of the property stolen from Brewer's Wharf—I went with him—he took me to a back place, a skittle-ground in the back-yard, where there were four tubs of butter—when he fetched me, he said he wished me to go with him to the house of the person who brought them—he said the person's name was Roberts—he took me to North-street, Whitechapel—it was a kind of chandler's-shop, and beer shop besides, a double house, with shop-windows on each side of the door—the shop was closed—I got in after Toy had called the people up—I did not find Ro
berts.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not you find Thomas Ro
berts's name over the shop door? A. Yes—Toy left me after that—I told him to come to Lambeth-street Office at eleven o'clock—he did so—he said he was willing to give me all the information in his power—when he said the butter was at his house, he said it was brought there overnight—I did not ask him what they were brought there for.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did he tell you at what time overnight? A. No—he did not say he had appointed for two officers to come at a later hour.

NATHANIEL BROWN . I am a labourer in the employ of Mr. Barber. I was there when the casks marked "I M R" came in—I chalked the letters "I M R" on several of them—here is part of my chalk-marks on one of the four produced—there is sufficient to enable me to say it is one of the casks I marked with chalk.

CHARLES PITTOCK
re-examined. The casks weighed from 100lbs. to 112lbs. each—here is the place on the side of the casks where the brand mark "IM R" has been taken out—the dairy mark has been erased.
COURT. Q. IS there enough to satisfy you the "IM R" has been there? A. There is no trace of the brand mark—
(The letter found on Northcote was here read as follows:—)
"London, Sept. 22, 1838.

DEAR JEM —I much regret the receipt of yours of this morning, not because you have called on me to send you some blunt, which I am pleased to do; I therefore enclose you 10s. You must be in a confounded rum state indeed, on a desolate island without a shot in the locker; however, this will serve to get you off a lee-shore and put you under weigh. Jones is home, and he found times so bad that he was forced to be sent home by the parish. However, I hope things will be better with you; yet I must be candid enough to say that we have all had a jolly laugh at your expenes. Mr. Jones, begs to be very kindly remembered to you, and at the same time he hopes that you will not be so far forgetful as to leave his shirts in the Isle of Wight; don't forget to take your regular dose, for Jones is very uneasy about your welfare. Wishing that you may receive this safe, and that it may be of service, I am yours truly, F. TOY."

(Barnard Jewell, tailor, Ship-alley, Wellclose-square; Lieut. William L. Gregg, R. N.; Charles Skinner, surgeon, Woburn-place; William Farrow, clerk to Barclay and Co.; Henry William Ward, wine-merchant, Seething-lane; George-Trail, master mariner and ship-owner, No. 31, Gloster-terrace, Commercial-road; James Rowden, engineer, No.7, Ratcliff-highway; John Savory, plumber, Ratcliff-highway; Charles Mason, wine and spirit-merchant, Well-street; Edward Gladwin, en
graver and printer, Ship-alley, Wellclose-square; Thomas Haines, boot-maker,

Ship-alley; Edwin Boys, commercial traveller, Ship-alley; and John Sladden, auctioneer and appraiser, Grove's-alley, Wellclose-square; deposed to Toy's good character: and John Hubbard, Lime-street, Fen-church-street; and William Taylor, commission agent, Denmark-street, Camberwell, to that of Christall: and John Penn, pewterer and engineer, Gray's-court; James Butler, carpenter, Little Prescott-street; Thomas Johnson, tailor, Alie-street, Goodman's-fields; John Marshall, boot
maker, Ann Howard and Job Newman, boot-maker, to that of Gregson.

VINCENT—
GUILTY . Aged.—
Judgment Respited.

NORTHCOTE—
GUILTY . Aged.

TOY—
GUILTY . Aged.

CHRISTALL—
GUILTY . Aged.

GREGSON—
GUILTY . Aged.

HOPKINS—
NOT GUILTY .

Of Receiving.
Judgment Respited.
(Toy was recommended to mercy by the Jury.)

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
813.
ELIZABETH BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of February, 1 pan, value 1s., the goods of
Edmund Butterick.

THOMAS ABBOTT . I live with my father, in Clerkenwell. On the 7th of February, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I saw the pri
soner take a pan from the prosecutor's shop, put it under her apron, and walk away—I ran in, and told Mr. Butterick—he came out, but could not find her—I know she is the person.

SAMUEL PERKINS . I saw a crowd on the 7th of February—I went up, and the prosecutor had got hold of a woman, but not the prisoner—I was afterwards going across St. John's-square, and met the prisoner with this pan.

EDMUND BUTTERICK . I keep an earthenware shop in Jerusalem-pas
sage. This is my pan—I do not know the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress.

GUILTY .* Aged 58.—
Confined One Year.

814.
JOHN HUTCHINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of January, 5lbs. weight of bacon, value 4s.; 41bs. weight of beef, value 2s.; and 4lbs. weight of mutton, value 2s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Morton.

JAMES GILLINGS (police-constable E 159.) I was in North-crescent, Tottenham Court-road, at one o'clock in the night, on the 28th of January, and saw the prisoner come up the prosecutrix's area, with a bag containing the articles named—I asked what he had been doing—he never spoke—I saw him get over the railing with this property—I found no money upon him, but a knife and a rope.

SARAH BUTCHER . I am servant to Mrs. Elizabeth Morton, of North
crescent. The prisoner had nothing to do with the house—these are my mistress's property, and it had been in the safe in the area.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress, and had no home.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

815.
CATHERINE BANKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of February, I shawl, value 5s., the goods of Michael Hawdon, from the person of
Ruth Hawdon.

RUTH HAWDON . I am the wife of Michael Hawdon—we live in Salis
bury-street near Portman-market. On the 1st of February, at half-past ten, or near eleven o'clock at night, I was passing from Broad-street to Russell-street, St. Giles's—the prisoner came and asked me if I had any money—I told her I had not—she watched her opportunity, snatched my shawl off me, and ran away—I watched her as far as I could, and called "Police"—the officers took her about ten minutes afterwards—I know her to be the same person—this is my shawl—(looking at it.) CHRISTIAN BURNETT. I saw the prosecutrix walking along, and saw the prisoner take the shawl from her shoulders, and run away with it in her hand—she came towards my door, and then ran into a court, where the policeman took her—I am sure the prisoner is the person.

JAMES BEDMAN (police-constable E 56.) I found the prisoner in Buck
ridge-street, coming out of a cellar—I did not find the shawl.
GEORGE HOBBY (police-constable E 129.) I found this shawl the next morning, at No. 13, Buckridge-street.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

816.
JAMES MACDONALD was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of January, 1 purse, value 6d.;1 handkerchief, value 6d.;1 hat, value 8s.; 9 sovereigns, 1 twopenny-piece, and 1 penny; the goods and monies of
John Pullen, from his person.

JOHN PULLEN . I was a waiter at the King's Head tavern, Islington, but have left. At a little after five o'clock in the morning, on the 23rd of January, I had been walking about all night—I had to call at a house that morning, and I went into the Three Hats, at Islington, to wait till I could go there—I was sober, but was fatigued, and I fell asleep on the form after I had been there an hour—there were some cab men and some women there, but I do not remember seeing the prisoner—when I went to sleep I had nine sovereigns, a silver twopenny-piece, and one penny-piese, in my purse, in my trowsers pocket—I had some copper in my waistcoat pocket, but I do not know how much—I had a good hat on—this is it—(looking at it)—when I awoke, about eight o'clock, my hat and money were all gone, except a few coppers, and an old hat was left in place of mine—the prisoner was taken the same evening—I know nothing of him.

JAMES FROST . I was pot-boy at the Three Hats. The prosecutor was there—he went to sleep—I saw the prisoner come in while he was asleep, and go away before he awoke—the prosecutor then complained of his loss, and I found this old hat there.

WILLIAM PAYNE . I live at No. 19, Lower-street, Islington. I work at a plasterer's, and have known the prisoner for four years—he lived near me—on the 23rd of January he called me out of doors, and asked whether I would go and pawn a hat for him—I said I did not mind—I went in doors and came out again, and then he asked if I would go and sell it in Petticoat-lane—I went there with him, and he sold it—after he had sold it he told me he had stolen that hat from a gentleman at the Three Hats, at Islington, and had left his old hat there—he said he took 9d. out of the gentleman's pocket, and that he got his hand under three
sovereigns, but he could not get them out—when he was taken I told all this.

DAVID BELASCO . I bought this hat of the prisoner for 4s., in Cutler-street, Houndsditch, near Petticoat-lane—the officer came to me afterwards—I had then sold it, but I knew who I had sold it to, and we got it.
WILLIAM CHINO (police-constable N 61.) I took the prisoner, and found the hat—the money has never been found.

GUILTY .* Aged 22.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

817.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of February, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, 4 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 1 purse, value 1d.; the goods and monies of
Mary Ann Roberts, from her person.

MARY ANN ROBEETS . I live in Norfolk-place, Waterloo-road. I was in Brydges-street, Strand, on the 3rd of February, about five o'clock in the morning—I had been out all night, and had taken a little drink, but I was quite sober, and had all my senses about me—I met a female whom I knew—she asked me if I had any money—I said I had—she said she had had nothing to eat all day—I took her into Mr. Thompson's, and gave her some bread and cheese and some gin—she then asked me to g ive her 1s., which I did not do—I came out—I have every reason to believe the prisoner fol
lowed me out of the house, but I did not see him there—he came up to me in Brydges-street, and put his hand on my shoulder—I requested him to take it off—he then put his hand in my bosom, and took out my purse—(I had changed a sovereign and taken the change, after giving the woman what I have spoken of)—I called out "Stop thief," and the officer took him—he said, "You may search me, I have got nothing"—the officer said "No, you have thrown it away"—another officer took it up—this is my purse, and the money in it.
Prisoner. I had been with her an hour and a half before then, walking arm in arm up Brydges-street. Witness. He was not with me at all.

WILLIAM CHAD WICK (police-constable F 71.) I was on duty, and heard the alarm—I saw the prisoner run away, pursued by this witness—I ran after him—he took something out of his pocket, and threw it down—I then took him, and he said, "I have nothing about me, search me"—I said, "It is no use searching you, you have thrown it away"—I held him till another officer came up with a lantern—he looked, and found this purse directly, with the money in it.
(Joseph Stone, a bootmaker, Horseshoe-court, Clement's-lane, and Hugh Smith, a tailor, gave the prisoner a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Transported for Ten Years.

818.
LOUISA KAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of January, 5 napkins, value 3s.; and 1 petticoat, value 2s.; the goods of
Joseph Dowden.

SARAH DOWDEN . I am the wife of Joseph Dowden, a labourer. We live in Market-street, Fitzroy-square—the prisoner lived near me with her mother—I left this petticoat and napkin hanging in my room, up one pair of stairs, about six o'clock in the morning, on the 24th of January—I returned at eight o'clock at night—they were then gone—these are them.
LOUISA DOWDEN . I am the prosecutrix's daughter. I was minding the door, on the 24th of January—I had the key of the room door in my hand—the prisoner came and took it from me.

THOMAS COWPER (police-constable E 141.) I apprehended the pri
soner on the 25th—she said she knew nothing about it—she then told me she did steal the things, but did not pledge them—I asked who did—she would not tell me the girl's name, but said they were pledged at Mr. Franklin's, in Tottenham-court-road.
JAMES GOLDEN . I live with Mr. Franklin, in Tottenham Court-road—I took in these things of a woman, but not the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 17. Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Fourteen Days.

819.
MIGUEL LOPEZ was indicted
for an indecent assault.
NOT GUILTY .

820.
HENRY COOK was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

RICHARD HOLLAND . I am a painter and glazier, and live in Tottenham Court-road. I had known the prisoner for four or five years—on the 17th of November I saw him at the Roebuck public-house—after we had been there a few minutes he said he had in his pocket a ticket to admit two per
sons to the Adelphi theatre any Tuesday or Thursday during the season, and if I liked to give him a trifle I might have it—I knew he had been a stage-manager at the Clarence theatre for three yean—I gave him 4d. for the ticket—I had no more money about me, or I might have given more—I went to the theatre on the Tuesday, and they would not let me in—the officer took the ticket from me—I believe this is it—(looking at a ticket.) Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you know he was in dis
tress? A. I believe he was, and his family also.

JOHN SHAW . I am constable of the Adelphi theatre. I was on duty, and was called up to the Pit to take this ticket—it is a forgery—the name on it is Baker—we have nobody in the house of that name—I have burnt upwards of 100 in the same hand-writing—one cheque taker took two in one night, and he had to pay for them.

FREDERICK WILLIAMS . I took the prisoner—I found at his lodging some seals with the same impression on it as is on this seal on this ticket—(read)—"Theatre Royal, Adelphi—two to the Pit any Tuesday or Thursday during the season.—HENRY BAKER."

GUILTY . Aged 39. Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Judgment Respited. (There were two other charges against the prisoner.)

821.
MARY ANN BURMAN was indicted
for concealing the birth of a child.
GUILTY . Aged 29. Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Twelve Months.

822.
JOHN BOILEAU was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JAMES GRACE. I keep the Colosseum hotel, Portland-road. I have known the prisoner two years and a half or three years—he has used my house occasionally—on Saturday evening, the 5th of January, I saw him—he said he was in the army, in the 90th regiment of foot, and produced me an army order—I believed it to be genuine, and advance dhim, at his request, six sovereigns—he went away, leaving me in possession of this order—he called again, and wanted 3l. or 4l. more—I got an officer, and took him into custody—I parted with my money, believing the representa
tion he made to be true.
SYDNEY CUMBERLAND. I am in the Army Pay-office. There is no

such person as John Boileau on the half-pay of the 90th regiment—there is a John Peter Boileau of that regiment—I am not acquainted with the signature of John Peter Boileau, and as many people do not use their second Christian name, it is possible this may be his—there was twelve months' pay due to John Peter Boileau, at 4s. 6d. a day—this is the usual order that is given—this order was presented to me—I would not pay it, as it was not filled up for John Peter Boileau—the person who presented it was not the officer.

Prisoner. Mr. Grace gave me the six sovereigns on the Saturday, and on Monday I was to call for some more—he told me to call the next day, and then I was taken—I have been on half-pay for many years, but not in the 90th regiment.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Twelve Months.

823.
MARY COLLINS was indicted for
a misdemeanor.

JOHN SHEARS . I am in the service of William Hilliar and another—they are linen-drapers.
Mr. Thomas Dean, of Albion cottages, Islington, was a customer of theirs—our firm allowed that person to have goods on credit—on the 22nd of October the prisoner came and said, "I want twelve yards of black silk for a dress for Mrs. Dean"—I had known the prisoner three or four years—she said, "Mrs. Dean does not wish to give more than 3s. or 3s. 3d. a yard"—she had twelve yards of black silk, which came to 1l. 7s.—I parted with it under the impression that her story was true, and that she came from Mrs. Dean—I did not discover it was not so till I called on Mrs. Dean.

MART ANN DEAN . I live in Albion cottages, Islington, and am the wife of Thomas Dean. I deal with Mr. Hilliar and another—I know the prisoner—I did not, on the 22nd of October, send her for any silk on my account, nor did I receive it.

JOHN NESBIT . I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 2nd of February—I asked her what she had done with the property—she said she had lost the duplicates, but it was pledged at certain pawn
brokers, which she named—I went and found the property, with the ex
ception of one or two things, which had been taken out—this is the black silk—(producing it.)

JOHN SHEARS
re-examined. This is the silk.
FRANCIS BEST . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this silk on the 23rd of October of a female, in the name of Ann Smith—I do not know who it was.

GUILTY . Aged 62.—
Confined Two Years. (There were several other charges against the prisoner.)

824.
JAMES MESSENGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of January, part of a plough, called the ground-plate, value 3s., and part of a plough called a mould, value 7s., the goods of
George Thomas Wanger—2nd COUNT, calling it 28lbs. of iron.
GEORGE THOMAS WANGER . I am a farmer, and live at Chingford, in Essex—I kept my plough under a shed. On the 28th of January, I

missed the ground-plate and mould-plate—I received information, and went to Walker's marine store shop on the 29th, and saw them—I do not know the prisoner—my house is about three miles from Walker's shop.

DINAH SAWKINS . I am servant to John Walker, of High-street, Tot
tenham. On the 28th of January, the prisoner came in between two and four o'clock—I purchased a quarter and 91bs. weight of iron of him for 1s., at the rate of 3s. a cwt., as cast-iron—he was in the habit of bringing bones and things there before—these two articles were among the iron.

NELSON SMITH , (police-constable of Edmonton, No, 5.) I went with the prosecutor to Walker's shop, and found this mould and ground-plate there—I fitted them to the prosecutor's plough, and they agreed.
THOMAS WOODROFFE CRAIG . I am a policeman. I apprehended the
prisoner—I told him the charge—he said he found the iron in the marshes,
and knew nothing about stealing it.
Prisoner's Defence, I picked up these things in a ditch in the marshes—I gather old iron, bones, and things.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

825.
WILLIAM HILL, alias James Hawkes,
was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of January, 3 sheets, value 6s.; 3 aprons, value 1s. 6d.;3 window blinds, value 1s. 6d.;3 handkerchiefs, value 1s. 6d.;1 shift, value 2s.; 2 printed books, value 6s.; 2 snuff-boxes, value 2s.; 1 tea
caddy, value 5s.; and 1 work-box, value 4s.; the goods of
Richard Stroud.

RICHARD STROUD . I live at Ilford, in Essex. A man named Hawkes lodged in my house, but I do not know that it was the prisoner—I never saw him myself till he was at Worship-street—on the 19th of January, between five and six o'clock, I lost the articles stated, and saw them at Spitalfields station-house on the 21st.

GEORGE TREW (police-constable H 125.) On the 19th of January, about four o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoner in Lamb-street, Spitalfields, with a bag—I asked what he had got—he said some linen and other articles—I asked where he brought them from—he said from Ilford, in Essex, and was going to sell them; that he was out of work and wanted victuals—I asked if the linen was marked—he said, "No"—I looked at the linen, and found it was marked "M. S." RICHARD STROUD re-examined. These articles are mine—"M S"are my wife's initials—her shift is marked "M S"—my sheets are marked.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where had yon left the things? A. In the sitting-room, in different places—I saw them safe about eight o'clock in the evening, when we went to bed—I cannot tell how they were taken—I believe the prisoner came home about twelve o'clock that night—his wife struck a light, and let him in—our room has no fastening to it—I came down just as he came in, and heard him talking to his wife, but I had never seen him myself—I had only been in the house five days—I know he was in distress, for when I went into their room, on missing the things, I saw nothing but a few turnips cut up, and there was no fire to cook them—the children had been crying for victuals for some days—I would employ him if the Court would allow him to go home.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

826.
GEORGE BAILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of January, 11/2 yard of carpet, value 5s., the goods of
Richard Etty; to which he pleaded

GUILTY —
Confined Three Months.

827.
JOHN SAWYER was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of January, 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d. the goods of
John Esterford, his master.

JOHN ESTERFORD . I am a shoemaker, and live at Royal Hill, Green
wich. The prisoner was in my employ in the beginning of January—I missed boots and shoes; and one day I missed a pair while he was waiting for his work, and found them in his basket, as he was going out of the shop with them—I found another pair of my boots at the pawnbroker's.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Was any thing said about your overlooking it if he confessed? A. Yes, I said I would overlook about the shoes—the boots were taken first—I have given him work for a year and a half—he calls at the shop for it, and goes away with it—I am quite certain I did not give him these boots to make—I never gave him more than two pairs to make at once—these boots were all ready for sale—they did not want any thing done to them—I did not give them to him as a pattern to make others by—I may have done such a thing, but I never gave him these—I saw them hanging on the door-post before he came into the shop, and when he was gone I missed them—he promised to give me the duplicates of these boots—he gave me one, but I could not find the other.

JOHN LEVICK . I am shopman to Mr. Nash, a pawnbroker, at Green
wich. On the 15th of January the prisoner pawned these boots for 1s.—he looked like a shoemaker, and they often pledge work.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Two Months.
(There were two other indictments against him.)

828.
ELIZABETH JONES, alias Taylor,
was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of January, 2 candlesticks, value 2s.; 1 towel, value 2d.; 1 tablecloth, value 2d.;1 fork, value 1d.; the goods of
Joseph Wilson: and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
George Henry Wilson.

GEORGE HENRY WILSON . I am a labourer, and live at Woolwich with my parents. On Saturday night, the 12th of January, the prisoner asked me to give her a night's lodging—I took her home, and she slept with me down stairs—my father and mother slept up stairs—when I awoke the next morning the prisoner was gone, and I missed my handkerchief—I had not given it to her.

DANIEL RIORDAN (police-constable R 207.) I met the prisoner in Green
wich market-place, on Sunday morning, the 13th of January, about nine o'clock—I observed a bundle under her arm, and asked if what she had belonged to herself—she said yes, it had belonged to her some time—I found she had two candlesticks, a tablecloth, a towel, and frock.
JANE WILSON . I am the wife of Joseph Wilson, a pensioner. These articles are his, except the handkerchief, which belongs to my son—the things were safe on Saturday night, at eleven o'clock.

Prisoners Defence. I was intoxicated when I met the policeman, and do not know what I said—I bought the things for 2s. 6d., of a man very much resembling the prosecutor, but he was dressed differently.

GEORGE HENRY WILSON
re-examined, I never sold nor gave them to her—I am certain she is the woman I took home that night—my mother. did not know the prisoner was coming to the house.

GUILTY , Aged 29.—
Confined Three Months.

829.
THOMAS DYSON and
GEORGE MORRIS were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of December, 1 till, value 1s.: 2 weights, value 1s.; 10 shillings, 12 pence, 24 halfpence, and 240 farthings; the goods and monies of
John Shove.

JOHN SHOVE . I am a corn-dealer, and live at Lewisham. On the 26th of December, about five or six o'clock, I left my till safe in the shop, and went into the back parlour—my man-servant at the same time went out at the front door—I cannot say whether the till was in the shop at that precise moment, although I believe, at the time of the examination, I did recollect a circumstance which enabled me to say it was the case positively—a few minutes after leaving my shop I heard what I thought was the rattling of the scale against the desk—I went into the shop, but saw no
body there—I went to the street door, and looked round, but could not per
ceive any one—a customer came in in a few minutes, and I then missed my till—there had been about 5s. in farthings, 2s. in other copper money, and from 10s. to 20s. in silver, in it—the scale was directly over the till—I know the prisoner Morris by his coming to the shop for a person who was an occasional customer, and he says, and I believe it is correct, that I gave him 1s. that afternoon as a Christmas-box—I might have given him that from the till, or from my pocket—the till is a drawer with divi
sions—the farthings were by themselves, the other coppers by themselves, and the silver by itself.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What day was it you lost your till? A. The 26th, boxing-day—I recollect giving Morris 1s. that day.

WILLIAM BEVINSTOCK . I am a labourer, and live at Lewisham
bridge. On the evening of the 26th of December, as I was going through the village, I saw the prisoner Dyson inside Mr. Shove's shop, leaning over the counter, and Morris looking in at the window—there was no
body else—I went on to Mr. Lindsay's, and on returning saw Dyson come outside with something under his arm—he called Morris by the name of George, and said, "Come on"—they walked together till they got into the road, and then went faster—I afterwards went to the Fox and Hounds, and saw both the prisoners down stairs in that house—Dyson asked me to fetch him a pot of ale, which I did, and he gave me twenty-four far
things to pay for it.
Dyson. I did not give him any money to fetch ale—I had some ale, and he drank with me. Witness. He asked me to drink, but I did not—I told him I had some up stairs.

Cross-examined. Q. What were you doing on this day? A. Going after some cheese for my mother—I have been in the service of Mr. Good
win, a builder, at Lewisham—I was not charged with stealing lead—three or four of us were at work, and there was some lead missing, but Mr. Good
win said he would employ me again—I have not been to him since—I left his service nearly a fortnight after the lead was missed—it was not as soon

as he found it out—the lead had been on the top of the house—Mr. Good
win said nothing to me about it, only to the others—he never discharged me and told me it was for that—I will not swear he did not tell me so—he did not send me away on account of missing the lead—it was Mr. Bean, the plumber—he told Mr. Goodwin of it—he charged others be
sides me—I have never been in custody in my life—I was in the hands of Barham the officer once, a good bit ago—I cannot say what it was about—I cannot recollect whether I have been in the hands of any other officer.

FRANCIS DUBOIS . I keep the Fox and Hounds beer-shop at Lewisham, about two hundred yards from Mr. Shove's shop. The prisoners came there, on the 26th of December, between six and seven o'clock—I cannot say whether they came together, but they were in the room together—they had some ale—they paid for part, and other people in the room paid for part—Morris paid for his in halfpence and pence, and Dyson paid in far
things—Beviostock fetched one pot of ale from the bar, and paid me twenty-four farthings for it—Morris was in the tap-room at the time, but not within hearing.
Dyson. Q. I came into your shop about seven o'clock? A. Yes; and you were there till I shut up between ten and eleven—there were from eighteen to twenty persons in the room that night.
GEORGE BARHAM . I am a constable of Lewisham. In consequence of information I apprehended Dyson, and found on him 3s. in silver and 4d. in halfpence—I received a quantity of farthings from Dubois.

Cross-examined. Q. What day did you take Dyson? A. I believe it was the 1st of January—there was one examination when he only was in custody—Morris was taken the following day—I have known Morris six years, and always knew him to be an honest industrious young man.

GEORGE ABBOTT . I am a constable of Lewisham. On the 26th of December, about six o'clock in the evening or a little after, I was passing Mr. Shove's shop, and saw Dyson standing against the window, and an-other, who I cannot swear to, stood on the other side of him—there was nobody in the shop.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you knew Morris before this transaction? A. Yes—I thought it was not Morris I saw, till I heard Bevinstock's evi
dence—I have known him from a child—he always bore a respectable cha
racter—I took another person before the Magistrate, who I thought it was.
NOT GUILTY .

830.
THOMAS DYSON was again indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of December, 22 cigars, value 3s. 8d., the goods of
William John Clements.

JOHN COWAN . I am apprentice to William John Clements, a hair
dresser, at Lewisham, about 150 yards from Mr. Dubois. On the 26th of December, about half-past eight or near nine o'clock at night, I came down stairs, and caught the prisoner at the sash of my master's window with one hand up to his right hand pocket, and the other hand in the window up to the elbow—I asked him what he wanted—he said, nothing, but held his head down, walked to the door, and ran—I ran after him, calling "Stop thief"—he got away—I missed about half an ounce of tobacco out of a jar, and some cigars from the window, also a pair of scissors and some razors—I found some cigars on the floor—I had seen the scissors at two o'clock that afternoon—the prisoner was in a situation to have taken the things—he did not ask to buy any thing, but ran out.

Prisoner. I did not go into his shop at all—it was said that a person in a flannel jacket took the cigars—Mr. Dubois knows I was in his house all the evening. Witness. I swear it was him—I am not mistaken—he ran over Lewisham-bridge, in a contrary direction to Dubois—he had a flannel jacket on like he has now—I knew him before by sight, but not by name—I am sure it was not Bevinstock—I am positive the prisoner is the lad.
Prisone. I had on a blue jacket that night.

FRANCIS DUBOIS . My beer-shop is about 200 yards from Clement's shop—the prisoner was at my house on the evening of the 26th—I cannot say whether he went out in the course of the evening—he came between six and seven o'clock, and he was there when I shut up at a quarter to eleven o'clock—nobody could go out without passing my bar, but I should not notice a person going out—there were eighteen or twenty in the house—if he had gone out, I should not have missed him—if a person ran over Lewisham-bridge, he could not get to my house, without return
ing over the bridge again, without he went some miles round—I did not notice what jacket the prisoner had on—he has brothers very much like him in appearance.

GEORGE BARHAM . I apprehended the prisoner on the 1st of January, on this charge—I found on him three shillings in silver, and fourpence in half-pence—he was dressed in a flannel jacket—he was at work at the time I took him, as a bricklayer's labourer—I have seen him in different dresses—I have seen him in a dark jacket—he sent for one to put on at the time I put him in the cage.
GEORGE ABBOTT . I saw the prisoner on the night of the 26th, a little after six o'clock—I can hardly say how he was dressed, but I think he had a bluejacket on.
NOT GUILTY .

831.
CHARLOTTE BARTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of January, I sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 1 half-penny, the monies of
James Thomas Francis, from his person.

JAMES THOMAS FRANCIS . I am a waterman. On the 13th of January, between nine and ten o'clock at night, I was walking up High-street, Deptford, in company with a friend, and went into the Centurion to have some refreshment—the prisoner came in while I was there, and called me by name—I took no notice of her, but came out, and went to the Lord Duncan—I came out of there, and walked down High-street—I got into conversation with her, and between Downing-street and Effingham-place, she put her hand into my waistcoat pocket, took out my money, and ran away with it—I ran after her, caught her, and took her into the Lord Duncan, where my friend was—I told him I had been robbed of my money—he asked her if she had any money about her—she said she had not a farthing—he saw she had something in her mouth, put his hand to her cheek, and found there was some money there—she directly ran out—I ran out after her, called a policeman, and gave her in charge—one half-crown, one shilling, and one half-penny were found in her mouth.

EDWARD CULMER . I was with the prosecutor on the 13th of January—in consequence of what he told me, I asked the prisoner if she had any money about her—she said she had not—I said, "If you have, you had better give it up to the young man"—she said she had no money at all about her—I said, "Don't say so, you have some in your mouth"—I put
my hand up to her cheek, and found money rattle in her mouth—she ran out—Francis followed, and gave her in charge.
Prisoner. They were intoxicated. Witness. We were not.

HENRY GUY (police-constable R 159.) On Sunday night, the 13th of January, I was on duty in Broadway, Deptford, and saw Francis and the prisoner—he told me she had robbed him of 1l. 7s., and desired me to take her into custody—I asked her if she had done so—she denied having taken any money at all, or having any—I took her to the station-house, and asked her to give me what she had in her mouth—she said she had nothing—I then took her by the throat, fearing she might swallow it, and she spat out a half-crown, and one shilling and one half-penny—the prosecutor was perfectly sober.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor on this evening while I was in company with a young woman—he gave me a quartern of rum to drink at the Centurion—I said I would not stop there, as it was so public—we then went to the Lord Duncan, and had something there—he said he wanted to speak to me, and we went out—he said, "Cannot I go home with you?"—I said, "No, you cannot"—he said, "Cannot you come up here with me?"—I went with him up High-street—he was so tipsy he could hardly walk, and was very dirty—he then said be had lost his money—we went to the Lord Duncan, and Culmer asked me if I had his money—I said no, I had none but my own—they began to pull me about, and fearing I should lose my money, I put it into my mouth.

J. T. FRANCIS re-examined. The prisoner came to me in the Centurion, and I gave her something to drink there—I gave her some
thing at the Lord Duncan also—I have known her from quite a child—her father and mother are dead—they were very respectable—her father was a warrant-officer—I never had any connexion with her in my life, but I understand she gets her living by walking the streets.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

832.
JOHN TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of January, 4 handkerchiefs, value 17s., the goods of
William Whistler.

CHARLES STEWART WARDEN . I am a constable of Woolwich. I produce some silk handkerchiefs which I received on Wednesday evening, the 23rd of January, from the serjeant-major of the rifle brigade—in con
sequence of information, I went to Mr. Whistler's shop at Greenwich, and afterwards to the barracks, and took the prisoner—I told him the charge—he said he had received the handkerchiefs from a girl at Deptford.

JOSEPH WILKINSON . I am a sergeant-major in the rifle brigade, stationed at Woolwich. The prisoner was a private in the corps—on the morning of the 23rd of January, I sent for him, and asked him if three handkerchiefs given to me by Ford, belonged to him—he said they did, and they were given to him by a girl at Deptford—he had one round his neck of the same pattern—I desired him to take that off, and reported it to the commanding officer, who desired me to give them to the constable to make inquiry about them—there was room for a dozen handkerchiefs under his waistcoat.

WILLIAM FORD . I am a sergeant in the rifle brigade. On the morning of the 23rd of January, I found a piece of silk handkerchiefs in a spare bed adjoining the prisoner's, concealed inside the mattrass—the bed was almost knocked down by nobody sleeping on it, and I doubled it up again
—I went into the yard, and found the prisoner had one of the same pattern round his neck—I asked him if those handkerchiefs belonged to him—he said yes, and that a girl gave them to him at Deptford.

JOHN WHISTLER . I assist my father, William Whistler, a draper at Greenwich. These silk handkerchiefs belong to him—I missed them, to the best of my recollection, on Tuesday evening, the 22nd of January—I had seen two riflemen in the shop that afternoon—I cannot recognise the prisoner as being one of them.

JAMES GOODWIN . I am a private in the rifle brigade. On Tuesday afternoon, the 22nd of January, I went to the prosecutor's shop with the prisoner, and bought a pair of stockings—the prisoner was dressed in his undress clothing, as he is now—I went from there to Deptford, and got to the barracks about eight o'clock in the evening—the prisoner parted com
pany with me for about three-quarters of an hour in Deptford—I did not notice the handkerchiefs in the shop.

Prisoner. Q. Was not I talking to you all the time I was in the shop? A. Yon were in the shop with me, and spoke to me about the stockings you wanted—you went across to the other side of the shop, and asked the price of another pair—the gentleman said they were 2s. 8d., and yon said it was too dear.

COURT. Q. Have the soldiers pockets in their clothes. A. Only watch
pockets, unless we have them put ourselves—his waistcoat was buttoned up in the shop.
Prisoner. I had these clothes on, and could not conceal any thing.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

833.
GEORGE SMITH, alias Batchelor,
was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of January, 1 coat, value 20s., the goods of
Samuel Burrows.

SAMCEL BURROWS . I keep a public-house in New-street, Deptford The prisoner came there on the 2nd of January) and bad a bed from Wed
nesday till Friday—he did not come on Friday night, but came again on Saturday, and about six o'clock that afternoon went out, faying be was going a little way, and should return that night—he did not come back, and I missed my coat five minutes after he was gone—he owed me about 4s. 9d.—he was taken on the Wednesday following—be belongs to the 1st rifle brigade, and told me he was on furlough—this is my—(looking at it.) SARAH W——. My husband is a pawnbroker at Greenwich The prisoner pawned this coat for 12s. on Saturday night, the 5th of January, about eight o'clock—I asked particularly if it was his own, and he said it was.
GUILTY . Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined One Month.

834.
WILLIAM WALLER was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Henry Walker Weatherstone on the 29th of January, putting him in fear and taking from his person, and against his will, 4 keys, value 10d.; 1 key ring, value 3d.: 6 half-crowns; 4 shillings; and 6 sixpences; his goods and monies.

HENRY WALKER WEATHERSTONE . I am master of a merchant vessel. On the 29th of January I was going down to my ship, and went to the Golden Anclior at Woolwich, to get refreshment at noon—I met the pri
soner

there, and treated him with a pot of ale—being intoxicated myself, I asked him to accompany me down to my ship—I was able to walk—he took me to a brothel in Woolwich—I do not know the name of the street—two girls came down stairs—I wished to retreat, and moved towards the door—the prisoner came and shoved me down on the floor—I received no bodily injury—when I was down, he put his hand into my pocket, and took 23s. or 24s. from my right hand breeches pocket—I am sure I had full that, and I might have had more—I made no resistance, further than taking his regimental cap off his head and I kept it—I called, "Police"—a woman appeared from an adjoining house, and called the prisoner by name, "Waller" as he was making his escape—she said something to him besides calling his name, but I cannot say what—I did not hear him make any reply—he went away with my money—I took his cap to the Arsenal the same night—this was between five and six o'clock—I had been in the prisoner's company all that time—I believe he was drunk too—be had some gin beside the ale I gave him—I was not drunk when I first met him—I am quite sure that the money was taken from me—I received no hurt—he bad three comrades with him at the Golden Anchor, but we left them there—I only gave them one pot of ale—I missed a bunch of keys, besides my money—I have not seen them since—I had got 9l. in gold in
my fob, which was not taken.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did the prisoner take you to the house at your request? A. Not to my knowledge—I think not—I was intoxicated, and cannot say whether he asked me to go there, or I asked him—I could see he was a soldier, and knew where to find him—I cannot tell how far the house was from the Golden Anchor—there were two women, the prisoner, and myself, in the room—I did not know the sort of house I was going to—I was standing with my back to the door, when this took place—the two women were going down stairs—they made their escape up-stairs, when I was thrown down—I saw them in the lock
up house next day—they were charged with pawning a Petersham great-coat, which I had left there when I went to the Arsenal—my silver was in my right pocket—I was thrown down on my back—I was not very drunk, but being a stranger I wished the prisoner to accompany me home—the women were on the opposite side of the room when I was thrown down—I did not see any body else in the room—it was a good large room—I was not struck—I think I was thrown backward by his arm—I saw his arm—I had not changed a sovereign or any thing at the public-house—I had changed a half-sovereign the night before—I had not counted my money at the public-house—I had not been to any other public-house.

ANN JOHNSTONE . I am a widow, and live at Woolwich. I let the house next door to me to a tenant—about six o'clock in the evening of the 29th of January, I was sitting in my own house, and heard a dreadful call of "Police" and "Murder" in the adjoining house—I beard a second call, and then I went and saw the prosecutor on the floor, and the prisoner on the top of him, but in what exact manner I cannot exactly tell, as the fire was low and there was no candle—I called out, "What in the name of goodness is there amiss?"—the prisoner jumped up, and I could see by his clothes that he was a gunner—the prosecutor lay still, as if confused or stunned—I called for a light, which was brought in a few moments, and two or three persons came—the pro
secutor still lay on the floor, and then I could see the prisoner who was

standing on the floor by him—I knew him directly the candle came, and I said, "I know you, Waller, you good-for-nothing man"—he said, "No, you don't know me"—I said, "Yes, I do; and you will find that to
morrow"—when the prosecutor got up he said he had got the cap of the soldier who had ill-used him—a gunner came in after the candle was brought—I did not know him.

Cross-examined. Q. What sort of a house is this, is it not a brothel? A. Of course it is your business to say so, but I know nothing of the kind—I never heard it called a brothel—it is not one, I swear that—there are only two rooms, which are let to two soldiers and their wives, as far as I know—I do not know the two young women who came down stairs—I have a man and his wife lodging in my own house named Evans—they are creditable people.

JOHN WELFORD . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery, the prisoner is also a gunner—he belonged to the same room as me at, the time of this transaction—I missed my cap on the Monday morning in question, and found the prisoner's cap on my bed—I had not seen him that morning—there were two beds in the room—the prisoner slept in the other—he did not sleep at home on Sunday night—I had seen my cap safe on Sunday—I was not in Johnstone's house on Monday evening, I was on duty—this I is the cap I lost.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you known the prisoner some time? A. Yes—he has borne an irreproachable character for honesty.

SAMUEL WATTS . I am a constable. On Tuesday evening about six o'clock, the prosecutor came to me at a public-house, where I was attend
ing an inquest on a convict, and applied to me to take a soldier in custody, who had rubbed him—he said he did not know his name, but he had got his cap, and had taken it to the Arsenal—I went to the Arsenal, and this cap was delivered to me—I have had it ever since—the prosecutor was intoxicated then, but seemed to have a knowledge of what he was saying—I took the prisoner up that night, with three others, for being disorderly in the street—he was intoxicated—the prosecutor saw him next morning and recognised him—5s. 2d. was found on the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

835.
THOMAS SCOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of June' 3 watches, value 15l., the goods of
Samuel M'Clellan, in his dwelling-house.

SAMUEL M'CLELLAN . I am a watchmaker, and live in Broadway, Deptford. On the 19th of June last I missed two gold watches and one silver one—I had seen them on the 15th hanging in my shop, at the side of the shop—they were worth 15l.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not see any body take them? A. No—I have seen the prisoner in the Broadway.

DANIEL LAZARUS DAVIS . I live in High-street, Chatham. On the 17th of July I took a watch in pledge, in the name of Benjamin Bone—I do not know the person who pawned it—there was "B. Bone" scratched in the case when he brought it to me—I have never seen the prisoner that I remember.

JOHN BONIFACE . I am a pastry-cook, and live at Deptford. On the 17th of July I met the prisoner in the Borough market, and went with him to Chatham by steam, and just beyond Gravesend, on the Rochester canal, he offered me a silver watch for sale—I did not buy it—I looked at it—it had

the name of "B. Bone" scratched inside the case—he said he had got two gold watches also to sell, but did not produce them—when we got to Chat
ham I saw him go into Mr. Davis's house, and pawn the silver one—he told me when he came out that he had got 30s. on it, and I saw that on the duplicate which he had—I did not ask where he got the watch—I know this to be the watch—(looking at it)—there were two B's in it when it was given to me—I do not find them there now—it was scratched in a similar manner to this inside, as if a name had been erased—I cannot swear this is the watch—I do not think this is the same watch, because the name was scratched deeply in.

DANIEL LAZARUS DAVIS
re-examined. I did not make any alteration in the watch, and you will find the name there now—I can see it now, though the witness cannot.

MR. PHILLIPS to JOHN BONIFACE. Q. Can you read? A. Yes—the watch I saw had "B. Bone" in it—it is inside one of these cases now—I was not aware it opened with a double case, and I only looked in one case—I see it now in this inner case—I have not seen it since the 17th of July, last year—I have known the prisoner for years—I have not quarrelled with him latterly—I have not spoken two words with him by way of anger—he served his apprenticeship to my father—we have had no quarrel—he never told me he had exchanged his watch with another person for his—I did not get any of this mosey—he did not lend me 10s. to buy an oven—he gave me change for a sovereign—I did not borrow any thing of him.
COURT. Q. Can yon now take on yourself to swear positively that is the watch he showed you? A. It is—he told me that he wrote the name "B. Bone" in it himself.

WILLIAM PHIPPS . I am a police inspector. I went with the prosecutor to look for his watch at Davis's, at Chatham—the watch now produced was shown to me there—I then went and apprehended the prisoner—he at first denied having been to Chatham to pawn the watch, but on the Sunday morning he sent word that he wanted to speak to me—I brought him into the charge room—he said he wished to speak the truth, that he pawned the watch, but he had got it from Michael Maddox—I took Maddox into cus
tody afterwards—he was remanded for a week, and then discharged.

Cross-examined. Q. You found there was a Michael Maddox? A. Yes—the prisoner gave me a minute description of him—Maddox denied all knowledge of it—I had a knowledge of him before—he is a very bad character—he lived at Deptford, but at present lives at Camberwell.

SAMUEL M'CLELLAN
re-examined, I hare the cap of the watch now, which was left behind on my premises—it fits this watch—I have not a doubt of the watch—I have not found the gold ones.

MR. PHILLIPS called WILLIAM BONIFACE. I am brother to the witness who has been ex
amined, and live in Church-street, Woolwich. I have known the prisoner about eleven years—he lived with me about four years, and then was ap
prenticed to my father—he was with him five years—my father died, and then he returned to me, and remained about twelve or sixteen months—he always bore a very honest character—I remember his having a silver watch—I gave it to him myself—the one produced is not it—I have seen this watch before, while he was working for me, in June last—he took it out of his pocket, and gave me an account of how he came to have this watch, and not the one I had given him.
COURT. Q. Did you examine the watch particularly? A. No—I was very busy at the time, and did not pay any attention to it—I never saw him with any gold watch.
NOT GUILTY .

836.
JOHN FREDERICK was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the shop of
Henry Simmons, on the 13th of January, and stealing therein eight horse-shoes, value 4s., his goods.

JAMES STARTUP . I am a blacksmith, in the employ of Henry Simmons, who has a little house near the cage, in the Greenwich-road. On Monday morning, about seven o'clock, when I went to work, I missed some horse-shoes off some pegs in the workshop, under a window, which I had seen safe on Saturday afternoon, when I left work—the wire-work which had been nailed over the window was torn away sufficiently to get a hand in, and the frame-work broken in—the glass had been broken before, and the wire was put to prevent a hand being put in.

WILLIAM PULLEY . I am a policeman. On Monday, the 14th of Janu
ary, I was in the yard of the Horse and Groom, at Blackheath, when the prisoner offered some horse-shoes for sale—I asked him where he got them—he said he found them in Back-lane, Blackheath—I asked if any one was with him when he found them—he said his younger brother Was, and they were wrapped up in an old horse-cloth—I told him to go and fetch his brother, and the cloth they were in—I waited for him half an hour—he did not return, and I went in search of him—I found him on Blackheath-hill afterwards, and took him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. CARDEN. Q. Were you in the yard when the prisoner came in? A. No, I was called in and found him there—I heard the smith ask what he wanted for them, and he said 1s.—this was full half a mile from the prosecutor's—they are all new shoes.

JOHN CLINKER . I am a farrier, at Blackheath-hill. The prisoner came to ray shop, and offered these eight shoes for sale—I called Pulley's atten
tion to it, who was standing outside the shop, and asked the prisoner what he wanted for them—he said 1s.—I asked where he got them—he said he found them on Back-hill, in a sack—I said, if he brought the sack I might tell who they belonged to—he was away a good while, and the policeman went and took him—he said he did not steal them—they are worth 3s. (Property produced and sworn to)
NOT GUILTY .

837.
THOMAS LOW and
THOMAS COOK were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 7th of February, 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s.; and 2 shirts, value 2s.; the goods of
William Quinton.
WILLIAM QUINTON . I am a carman, and live at Lea. I lost a coat, waistcoat, and two shirts, on the morning of the 2nd of February—the shirts hung to dry on a hedge near the house.

WILLIAM DYKE . I am a constable. On the 7th of February, at ten o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoners in Lewisham, about half a mile from Lee—Low had a bundle—I asked what he had got there—he said a coat, which he had given to him—I asked what was in his bosom—he said a shirt and waistcoat—I found two shirts and a waistcoat on him, and four farthings on Cook—be said he knew nothing about it—I had seen them both in company, about an hour before.
JANE QUINTON . I know these clothes to be my husband's.

LOW—
GUILTY .* Aged 17.

COOK—
GUILTY .* Aged 18.
Confined Six Months.

838.
JOHN WRIGHT . was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of feb
ruary, 37 sash-weights, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Pitch.

ROBERT PITCH . I am a carpenter. I was employed building a house, at Blackheath-hill, and had some window-weights in the house—I missed them on Monday, the 4th of February—I had seen them at a quarter past six o'clock on Saturday evening the 2nd, these are them—(looking at them.) JOHN LEDGER. I am a policeman. I was on duty at Deptford, on Saturday night, between eight and nine o'clock, and met the prisoner, with something on his shoulder—I asked what he had got—he said, some weights—I asked where he brought them from—he said, from Chatham—I said I doubted that—he then said he brought them from Blackheath—I asked where he was going to take them to—he said he did not know—I took him to the station-house, and next morning, as I was taking him to the office, he said he got them from a new house, at the top of Blackheath-hill—I went there, and found the prosecutor.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the 'weights in front of an unfinished house, as I was coming down Blackheath-hill.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Month.

839.
JOHN SHAW was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of January, I till, value 1s.; 1 shilling, 4 pence, 1 halfpenny, and 1 farthing; the goods and monies of
William Brown; to which he pleaded
GUILTY .*—
Transported for Seven Years.

840.
JOHN WOOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of January, 1 till, value 1s.; 24 pence, 12 halfpence, and 24 farthings; the goods and monies of
Henry Litchford.

MART ANNE LITCHFORD . I am the wife of Henry Litchford, an en
gineer, and live at Woolwich. On the afternoon of the 9th of January, at three o'clock, my till was safe; and at four o'clock I went to get some. change, and it was gone—it was found in a market-garden—it had con
tained about 3s.—there was some copper money, and a great many farthings—I did not see the prisoner.

BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant R 15.) On the 9th of January I was at the station-house when one Shore was brought in—the officer stated there was a till stolen—I went and found the prisoner that night—he said that Shore stole it, and threw it into a garden, and gave him 1s.
NOT GUILTY

841.
JOHN FREDERICK FRANCK was indicted
for embezzle
ment.

LEIGH WEAVER . I am a linen-draper, and live at Greenwich. The prisoner was my cashier—the shopmen have each separate books, in which they enter what they receive, and take it to the cashier at his desk—they give him a small cheque—here are three of the cheques for the sums stated—the prisoner has entered in his own book the right amounts, and after
wards erased the "ten," and altered the young men's books as well to make them tally—in each case he has erased the "1" with a pen, so that he
did not account to me for the sums he received, but minus the ten shillings.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. The books are kept by the young men? A. Yes, and where there has been 14s. 2d. inserted in pen
cil, the "1" has been rubbed out—I have no knowledge of when it was done—the cashier accounts to me—I have all the books here.

ALFRED SELWOOD. I serve in the prosecutor's shop. I keep a book—this is it—it is not dated but to the 34th cheque I paid the cashier 14s. 21/2d., and to the 39th cheque 15s. 51/2d., which have been both altered, and the "1" erased.
HENRY BROOME . I am assistant to Mr. Weaver. I paid 11s. 10d. to the prisoner—the "1" has been erased in my book.
NOT GUILTY .

842.
JOHN CROUCH the younger, was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 1 coat, value 1l. the goods of
William Henry Crouch; also on the 16th of January, 1 watch, value 12s.; 1 flute, value 4s; and a book, value 1s.; the goods of
John Crouch the elder; to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

843.
WILLIAM ROBBS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of January, 2 hampers, value 2s. 6d. the goods of
Thomas Moody.

OLIVIA MOODY . I am the wife of Thomas Moody, a basket-maker, at Greenwich. On the 7th of January, these hampers were safe at my door, at seven o'clock in the evening, at half-past seven o'clock I found them at the station-house—the small one I swear to—I lost one like the other, and believe it is mine.
WILLIAM MOODY . I know this large hamper—I made it myself.

GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) I fell in with the prisoner at a quarter-past seven o'clock that evening, two or three hundred yards from the prosecutor's—he had a military cloak on, and something under it—as he passed me he said, "My knapsack is d—d heavy"—I went after him and said, "What have you got?"—he said, "Baskets, to be sure"—I asked what he was going to do with them—he said he did not know, he was going to Woolwich, and he had got a pass—I said he must go with me—he went a little way, then threw off his cloak aid the hamper, and became very violent—he collared me, and I collared him—he tried to bite my face—he knocked my hat off—he bit my arm and drew blood—he had been drinking.
Cross-examined. Q. What did you find on him? A. 3s. 6d.

ALEXANDER MIDDLETON . I am a sergeant of the Scotch Fuasileer Guards. The prisoner belonged to that regiment—his conduct has been remarkably good, but he had a fracture on his head—I have seen him when he has been drinking, and then he does not know what he is doing.
NOT GUILTY .

844.
JOSEPH BRICE was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of Decem
ber, 123/4 lbs. weight of mutton, value 6s., the goods of
Richard Beaumont Burnaby.

JAMBS MORRIS , I am a constable of Plumstead. Mr. Richard Beau
mont Burnaby is a captain in the Royal Artillery, and lives at the academy, on Woolwich-common—I know the prisoner—his friends are very respect
able

—his father is a pensioner of the Royal Artillery—on the 5th of De
cember, about eight o'clock at night, I saw him with something under his arm at the corner of a plantation attached to the academy—I said, "What have you got there?"—he dropped it and ran—I said, "It is no use to run away, I know you"—I pursued him to Jackson's-lane, and there lost him—I returned to where he had dropped something, and found a leg and loin of mutton—I knew the prisoner, but I did not know where he lived—his jacket was afterwards found at his father's, in Jackson's-lane—it had a small piece of meat on it and some marks of fat.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you in the police? A. No—the prisoner was afterwards found in bed—I was not told he had been in bed ever since a little after seven o'clock—I went to the house of one Col
lins that night—I did not tell him that it was a lad of the name of Smith—I have never said so—I have been accused of forging a Magistrate's name to an order for payment of money—I am not aware that any boys were ever taken up, and committed on my oath, and that the Magistrate afterwards discharged them on its being proved that I had sworn falsely—I do not know that there is a warrant now against me for forgery—I believe there is.
DAVID GRAHAM . I am in the service of Captain Burnaby. This mutton is his, and was taken from the safe—I have no mark on it, but he lost some like this.
NOT GUILTY .

845.
ROBERT GEE was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of January, 1 box, value 5s. 6d. the goods of
Lewis Davis.

JOSEPH WEIGHT . I am a constable of Woolwich. On the 8th of January, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner take a box out of Mr. Davis's shop, and run away—I pursued, and brought him back—he had to reach inside to get it.

JAMES LAMB . I am assistant to Mr. Lewis Davis, of Tower-street, Woolwich, a pawnbroker. This box is his—we had some like this standing inside the door—I could not swear whether it was sold or stolen.
JAMES HENRY WATTS . I am an ironmonger. I was with Weight, and saw the prisoner take the box from inside Mr. Davis's shop.
Prisoner. Q. Had I any thing with me? A. Yes, a bundle containing a gown.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to that shop on some business of my own—I cannot say how I got the box, but I must have paid for it—I had the fever very bad in Jamaica, and since that I sometimes do not know what I am doing.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Four Days.

846.
WILLIAM SMITH . was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of January, 1 house-tie, value 2s., and 1 weight, value 1d., the goods of
Wil
liam Pershouse, his master.

GEORGE JAMES PULLEN . I am servant to Mr. William Pershouse, a coach-master and a farmer, who lives at Greenwich. Some pieces of iron were taken from a wall that was pulled down, and put into a loft of his—the
prisoner had worked there as a labourer—the policeman brought this piece of iron and weight to my master.
JOHN DENNIS . I made this house-tie for Mr. Pershouse, nearly two years ago—I made three more at the time, and it cost two shillings, or half-a-crown—as old iron, it is worth 6d. or 8d.

JOHN WALKER (police-constable R 182.) I met the prisoner with a bag on his back, on Tuesday, the 15th of January—I asked him what he had got there—he said it was no business of mine—I took the bag from him—he ran away, about thirty yards—I then overtook him—he said he had just picked the bag up in the road—it was quite dry, but it was a very muddy night—it contained this 1/4 cwt., and this iron tie.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not say that a man threw it out of the loft for me to sell? A. You said, when yon returned from the Magistrate, that a man named Banks threw it out of the loft, and told you to sell it for old iron—Banks has since absconded.

GEORGE JAMES PULLEN . re-examined. We had a weight of this desorip
tion, and I believe this is it.
Prisoner. Q. Was I ever in the loft? A. Yes, occasionally, I believe, I and Banks was in the loft.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked them op in the road—I had not worked at the place for some time.

GUILTY . Aged 70.—
Confined One Month.

847.
ANN PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of November, 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 shawls, value 10s.; and 1 tippet, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Louisa Jackson.

LOUISA JACKSON . I live at Deptford, and am single. The prisoner lodged in my house—her husband is a whitesmith—they came there on the 4th of June—this property was in a trunk which was locked, and was in her room—on the 19th of January, I found the trunk broken open, and these things were gone—the prisoner had left then—I spoke to her about it—she said she had done wrong, and I was to give charge of her at the police-office—this is my property—(looking at it.)

JAMES BUCHANAN . I am in the service of a pawnbroker at Deptford—I have a coat and shawl, pawned in the name of Ann Phillips—I do not know who by, but the prisoner pawned a pair of boots in the same name.
HAMMOND SMITH . I took the prisoner into custody. The duplicates were found in the box which the property was taken from.
MART WARNER DALTON . On the 19th of January the prisoner brought
this tippet to me for sale, between nine and ten o'clock in the morning—I bought it of her.
Prisoner. I am sorry for what I have done, and throw myself on the
mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 64.—
Confined Six Months.

848.
HENRY JAMES GARDNER was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January, 1 pair of spectacles, value 7s., the goods of
George King; and
MARY GARDNER
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

MARY KING. I am the wife of George King—we keep a cookshop in Butcher-row, Deptford. Henry James Gardner came on the 19th of Janu
ary,
between three and four o'clock, for a basin of soup—I left him there while I went to warm the soup—after he was gone I missed my spectacles—I knew him before.

MARY WHITCOMBE . I live with my mother. Mrs. Gardner asked me to go on an errand for her—I said I would—it was to pawn a pair of spec
tacles in the name of "Johnson, No, 5, Rope-walk," for 2s.—I pawned them, and gave her the money.
Mary Gardner. I did not tell you you were to pawn them in the name of Johnson, it was Henry told you so, and if they asked you where, to say, the Rope-walk. Witness. It was you told me so.
JAMES FANCHON . I am a pawnbroker. I took in these spectacles in the name of "Mary Johnson, Rope-walk."
BENJAMIN LOVELL . I am a police-sergeant. I got the duplicate from Mary Gardner, and found the spectacles.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Henry James Gardner's Defence. I went for the soup, and on the form was the spectacles—I asked my mother to ask the little girl to go and pawn them for me—I told my mother that a chap owed me some money, and be gave me these to pawn.

HENRY JAMES GARDNER—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months.

MARY GARDNER.—
NOT GUILTY .

849.
WILLIAM HOLLIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of January, 6 pairs of combs, value 2s., the goods of
Mary Ann Davies.

MARY ANN DAVIES . I keep a stationer's shop at Deptford—I sell combs. On the 19th of January the prisoner came into my shop to offer matches for sale—I did not want any—I had an opportunity of seeing him, and I believe he is the boy—soon after he was gone I missed six pairs of combs from the window—it was then a little after twelve o'clock—soon afterwards the prisoner was taken by the officer—I saw these six pairs of combs, which I believe are mine—they were all fastened together when I lost them, but they have been cut.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You have a good business? A. Not very good—I never saw the prisoner before—I was in the parlour when he came into the shop—there is a glass-door to the parlour—I was in the shop about three minutes before—there is a sliding-board at the back of the window, and that was open—I had looked into the window a very short time before, and had set the board to rights—I believe these combs are mine—they are very common—I merely speak to them from having seen them frequently, and from their size.

URIAH EDEN . (police-constable R 81.) I took these combs from the prisoner at five o'clock that day—he was offering them for sale in Church-street, which is a mile from the prosecutrix's—he had another in a handker
chief—as they were common combs, I let him go—he was afterwards taken by another officer—I met him again about twenty minutes after.

GUILTY .** Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years—To the Convict Ship.

850.
CHRISTIANA SPICE was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of January, I tablecloth, value 10s.; 1 petticoat, value 4s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.;1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 apron, value 1s.; 1 shawl, value 1s.; 1 pair of pattens, value 3d.; and 1 pair of stockings, value 3d.; the goods of
Sarah Grubb.

SARAH GRUBB . I am a widow, and live in King-street, Blarkfriars-road. I employed the prisoner to look after my children in my absence, and paid her 6d. a day—she found her own food—on Friday, the 4th of January, I left her in charge of the children, and on returning, about seven o'clock in the evening, she was gone—I missed the articles stated, which are worth more than 1l.—the prisoner boarded and lodged in the house for three months—I found her again on the 6th of January.
WILLIAM WEST . I am shopman to Mr. Wharton, pawnbroker, Mount-street, Westminster-road. I produce a tablecloth, pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of January.

ROBERT OVENDEN . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge. I found the shawl on her, the pattens on her feet, and the stockings on her legs—I found duplicates of the other property on her, which the pawn
brokers have given up. (Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence, I am not guilty of taking any thing—the apron was lent me—the other things I certainly had.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

851.
JOHN PASSFIELD was indicted
for killing and slaying
John Edward Passfield.

JOHN BOULTER . I am a turner. I have known the prisoner five or six years—he is a plasterer, bricklayer, and carpenter; a handy sort of man, and got his living in that way—he has worked for me—he did three weeks' work for me about five weeks ago—he finished it on the 17th of Novem
ber—the deceased died on the 29th of December—the prisoner had about five days and three quarters' work from me between those times—he had two children, one girl and one boy, (the deceased,) who was between six and seven years old—his wife has been dead about two years—he had a guinea a week when he worked for me—he would have the means of sup
porting his family, when in employment—I believe he sometimes got more from other people—during part of the time he worked for me, he lived in Robert-street, or Ann-street—he never rented the place in Counter alley—he merely lived there on sufferance—on the 28th of December, the day before his child died, I went there with the policeman—the door was open, and we walked into the room, on the ground-floor—the girl and boy were both lying in one corner of the room on some shavings—the policeman asked the boy whether he had had any victuals that day—he said "Yes," he had had some bread—he did not say who had given it to him—there was nothing in the room but a few empty baskets—no kind of furniture at all, nor any fire—I asked the child where his father was, he said be did not know—in consequence of what I saw, I immediately went to the beadle

—he was not at home—I left my card, requesting he would attend to the case early in the morning—the beadle did not come down next morning, and in the after part of the day I sent my boy, who brought word that the child was dead—I went again to the beadle, who was not at home, and left word that the child was dead—the child had had the hooping
cough—it coughed while I was there—and I understand he had the measles, but I do not know—I have known the prisoner six or seven years—he might have done better for his children, if disposed—there was neglect, I think—I always found him very willing to work when I sent for him—I know he could not always find employment, because he applied to me for work.

JURY. Q. DO you consider him in full possession of his intellect? A. I know nothing to the contrary—I never observed any deficiency at all—he was very handy in what he undertook to do—the whole employ
ment he had from me since the 17th of November, was five days and three quarters—I believe he had a little work elsewhere, but he wanted to work for me, I had some which I said I could not have done till after Christmas—I really think, at the time, that he was in great need of the means of providing for himself and children—he had three quarters of a day's work on the 30th of November.

MARGARET PASSFIELD . I am the prisoner's daughter, and am thir
teen years old. I think my brother was between six and seven years—I do not know the day of the month he died—he had been ill about three weeks or a month before he died—he complained of his head being bad—he had the measles, I believe, and he used to cough—I never heard him hoop—he had had a cough a good while before he died—he died in Counter-alley—I remember Mr. Boulter coming there the day before he died—we had nothing but a few shavings there, no bed or bed-clothes—we had something to eat that day and the day before—my father gave us all he could—he was not in employment at the time my brother died—when my father had food he gave it to us as well as took it himself—I never knew him take food himself and not give us any—he did not go and ask for medical assistance when my brother was ill—I had had some bread to eat the day Mr. Boulter came, and my brother too—my father had not long been gone out when Mr. Boulter came—he was gone to see and get us some victuals—he slept in the same room with us, on the shavings—he al
ways gave us part of what he had—he was pretty kind to us—we had been living there about a month, I believe—my brother had a very bad cough—he coughed at night—my father would sometimes spend his money some
where else—he used to get us in some victuals first, and then he used to go out, leaving me and my brother in the house by ourselves—he sometimes came home drunk, not very often, and not when we were without food—we have not been a day, I think, without something or other—we sometimes got bread and dripping, and sometimes bread and potatoes—sometimes we had bread given to us—sometimes people gave us victuals, and sometimes they would not—my brother had a coat given to him, and a pair of trowsers my father gave him, and a shirt my father bought him—I know Mrs. Bant
lin—my father slept at her place once on the floor—my brother was well then—it was before he was taken bad, not long before—we had only some old pieces of baize and carpets over us—my brother had no doctor—he was very bad for about three weeks or a month, and about a day or two before he died he could not stand up on his legs—he died on Saturday—the

night before he died he had some gruel and bread, and ate very heartily—he had as much as he wished—we were not in great want of food while we were in Counter-alley—we were never without some supply of food—my father did not give my brother the gruel and bread—Mr. Boulter sent the gruel—when my father was in employment he supplied us with food and firing—we came from the workhouse about two years or a year and a half ago, at Nessing, in Essex—we had not enough victuals there, and my father took us out—he was in the workhouse also—I did not tell him we had not enough food there—he knew it himself—he knew how much we had—he used to give my brother part of the food given to him, because he was in the same ward—he was kind to my brother.

JURY. Q. Did your brother's legs swell much before his death? A. No; my father got drunk when he got work, but he would get us in some victuals first, and then go out—he would get us about two quartern loaves, or a quartern and a half, and coals and potatoes, and a bit of dripping—he would then go to the public-house, and come home about eight or nine o'clock, sometimes.

FRANCES BANTLIN . I am the wife of William Bantlin, a traveller. I have known the prisoner ten years—we rent an apartment in the house, in Counter-alley, Newington—we moved there on the 19th of November, and the prisoner came to help us move—he then lived in Ann-street—the prisoner asked me, as it was so late that sight, to let him stop there, and he made shift on the floor—the children were afterwards brought there, while I was away, not to the same house as me, but the next house—I believe he gave his children part of what he had himself, as far as laid in his power—I believe he was out of work about the time of the child's death—I do not think he neglected them through getting liquor, but one and another person, who knew him in his trade, I believe, gave him liquor—I do not think it was at his own expense—I do not think, while he was there, he had sufficient to support the children—I have seen him give them food—they never complained to me that he neglected them—I understand that the children's mother, on her death-bed, requested he would not put them in the workhouse—I saw the child the evening before he died, and he looked very bad—(I went in with Mr. Boulter's boy)—I had not seen him for two or three days before—he used to come up, and sit by my fire-side, when the father had not power to get a fire—he had not the hooping-cough, but he had a consumptive cough, and he had the measles—I think he caught cold, for the girl brought him out the day after he had the measles out on him, and I think they struck in—as far as I saw, the prisoner brought them bread and meat, or whatever he could get, and gave them the same as himself—I never saw any neglect—he was particularly kind to the boy—I believe he was out of employ a fortnight or three weeks before the boy's death—I know he had nothing to do in the Christmas week, for my husband made him come and dine with us, and the child also—I advised him to get an order for the parish doctor, who would give him a note to go to the Board for relief—I cannot recollect exactly what he said at that moment, but he said at times that all the doctors in the world could not save him, for he had had a complaint from his infancy—the child had had the small-pox about four months before—I am not at all aware of any in
tentional neglect.
EDWARD ILIFF . I am a beadle of Trinity Church, Newington. In consequence of information, I went to Counter-alley on Sunday, the 30th

of December, the day after the boy's death—I found every thing in as bad a state as possible—I went immediately on the commencement of the morn
ing service—I found the prisoner there, lying in one corner of the room, on some wood shavings—there was no furniture whatever in the room—there was some fire—the prisoner appeared in a state of stupor—I could make nothing of him at first—I found the child dead, lying on a log of wood, in an opposite corner of the room, covered over with a sort of rug—the girl Was sitting by the fire—there was nothing whatever in the house in the shape of food—I asked the girl, "Have you had any thing to eat to-day?"—she said at first, "No"—whether she understood me I do not know—I said, "You are sure you have had nothing to eat to-day?" and the prisoner answered, "No"—the girl said, "I have had a little bread"—I asked her who supplied what she had—she said, "Mr. Boulter, it was part of what was left the night before"—I asked the prisoner if he was hungry—he said, "Yes"—I fetched them some bread and bacon—they did not eat it in the way I have seen poor people eat sometimes—they cooked it first—when I found he had filled his belly, I said, "I am a constable, and it is necessary you should give me some information respecting the death of this child, or I must take you into custody—there is a report that this child has been very much neglected"—(for, while they were preparing their refreshment, I had been out to make inquiry in the neighbourhood)—he said, "We have been short"—I asked what was the cause of it—he said he had not employ
ment, and no means of getting it for them—I said, "Have you made any ap
