plication for parochial assistance in your extremities, or medical advice for the child?"—he said no, he had not, in that instance, and the reason he gave was, because he had before that time been passed on to his parish, which was Nessing, in Essex, which he had left, thinking he could do better by coming to town; and I think the girl said, they left because they had not victuals enough there—I do not think the prisoner made that observation—I asked him if he had neglected the children in consequence of cohabit
ing with some woman—he said, the children and himself had certainly been very short, but he could certainly acquit himself of any thing like neglect—he said nothing about the woman—he made the same observation afterwards, on the way to the station-house.

WILLIAM BARNARD BODY . I am a surgeon. I did not see the child before death—I saw it on Sunday, the 30th of December, but did not open the body till the following day—it appeared very much emaciated—I could see nothing to account for death—there was no appearance of exter
nal marks—on opening the body I found a disease of the lungs, adhesion of the pleura, and a large abscess, which had broken—it died from con
sumption, which must have been going on for some time—supposing it to have had small-pox, then measles and hooping-cough, that might produce consumption, but not necessarily so—all the viscera of the stomach was in a state of health—the stomach was quite empty, but it appeared that during the night the child had a very severe diarrhcea—I have no means of judg
ing whether disease was produced by want of food—even supposing there had been neglect, it was impossible to ascertain it decidedly in that state—I cannot say the child died from neglect of being supplied with food—whe
ther the emaciation was the result of consumption or want of food I cannot state—there is hectic fever with consumption—that would produce very great emaciation—there is no distinction between emaciation produced by disease and shortness of food.
MR. BOULTER re-examined. I always found the prisoner ready to come to work—I never knew him harsh or severe to his children.
NOT GUILTY .

852.
WILLIAM LAMBERT,
JOHN DONOVAN , and
JOHN FOSTER , were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Pillow, at St. John, Southwark, about the hour of one in the night of the 24th of January, with intent to steal, and steal
ing therein, 1 veil, value 10s.; 1 spoon, value 5s.; 2 buttons, value 1s.; 1 pair of braces, value 3d.;1 cloak, value 4l.;3 coats, value 5l. 10s.; I tooth-pick, value 1s. 6d.;1 knife, value 3d.;1 rupee, value 2s.; 1 half-franc, value 5d.;5 crowns, 4 half-crowns, and 10 shillings; his property; and that Lambert had been before convicted of felony.

MR. PAYNE conducted the Prosecution. JOHN PILLOW. I am a printer, and live in Horsleydown-lane. On Thursday night, the 24th of January, I went to bed about twelve o'clock—I got up about half-past six o'clock next morning, and went into the kitchen—I found the kitchen window wide open, and a pane of glass partly broken—I had not noticed the window the night before—I found my writing-desk on the kitchen table—it had been brought from the par
lour—it was closed, but I found it was broken open—it had contained va
rious papers and a bag of money—I found the papers scattered about the room—there were five crown-pieces, four or five new half-crowns, a few shillings and sixpences, and two or three fourpenny-pieces, in the bag—I had preserved them, being new, not meaning to circulate them, except the crown-pieces, which were not quite new—I found a tin box in the kitchen, that had been in a drawer in the parlour the night before—I did not see it the night before, and cannot say when I saw it last—the parlour is in the front of the house, and the kitchen quite at the back—there are five or six steps from the kitchen to the parlour—there had been a guinea, a half
guinea, and a few new shillings and sixpences, in the tin box—a small wooden box was left in the parlour, which had contained a little Indian rupee, some copper coin, a pair of shirt-buttons with "E P" engraved on them, a few cents, a half-franc, and a small plated copper coin—I have seen them since—I have missed a great deal of wearing-apparel—there was a blue cloth cloak with a lynx-fur collar, a great-coat, a suit of black, a claret dress
coat, and another olive green great-coat, which I had thrown off in thekitchen the night before—there was a silver tooth-pick in the pocket of the black

waistcoat—a veil was also missing, and a silver caddy-spoon, engraved "J A P," which were my first wife's initials, that had been in the tea
caddy in the parlour—a penknife was also missing from the parlour—the lock of the parlour door was shot when I went to bed the night before, but the key was left in it—the kitchen window opens into the yard, which is enclosed by a wall seven or eight feet high—on the other side of the wall is a public lane—a person could get over—a hand could be got in where the window was broken, to open it—it was broken close to the fast
ening—I found half of the square of glass next morning laid carefully against the wash-house window—the window is not more than three or four feet from the ground—a person could get in without assistance—it is a paved yard.

PETER LOGAN (police-sergeant N 12.) I was sent for to the prosecutor's on Friday morning, the 25th, about half-past seven o'clock—the house is in the parish of St. John, Horsleydown—I picked up this duplicate in the

back-yard—it was afterwards shown to the prisoner Donovan at the station-house, and he claimed it as his own—it has the name of John Donovan on it—I had sent Sergeant Woodhouse to take him on finding it.

JOHN BRIDOELAND (police-constable N 123.) On Thursday night, or Friday morning, the 25th of January, at a quarter before one o'clock, I saw the prisoners Lambert and Donovan together in Tooley-street, about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's house—they went down Unicorn-square—Donovan had a blue cloak on, with a dark fur collar—they were going in a direction from the prosecutor's—I went round my beat, and about one o'clock I saw them both coming back in a direction towards the prosecu
tor's—Donovan then had on a black frock coat, and no cloak—they were going towards the prosecutor's the last time.

WILLIAM FETHERTON (police-sergeant N 17.) On Friday morning, the 25th of January, at half-past four o'clock, I saw the three prisoners in the Crown public-house, High-street, near St. George's Church—it is a market house, and is always open about a quarter past four o'clock—they remained there till about twenty minutes before six o'clock—they then came out with two or three others, and went towards London-bridge—that was all I saw of them at that time.

Foster. The statement is perfectly correct—I spoke to him, and asked him to have a cup of coffee. Witness. He did speak to me outside the house, MARY HARRISON. I am sister to Mrs. Pillow. On the night of the robbery I fastened the kitchen window, between seven and eight o'clock—I went to bed at eleven o'clock—I saw every thing safe before I went to bed—I looked at the fastening at eleven o'clock, before I went to bed, and it was all secure—there was no pane of glass broken then—the doors were quite fast—Mr. Pillow fastened the back door—he went to bed before me—the desk was in the parlour—there was no desk on the kitchen table then.

JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-constable N 13.) In consequence of infor
mation I received I went with another constable to Unicorn-square, on Friday morning, about a quarter past eight o'clock, and saw the three pri
soners soners in company together in the square, near Lambert's sister's house—I laid hold of Lambert and Donovan, and told them what I wanted them for—they both said they would not go—they made great resistance, and Foster said to Lambert, "Bill, you had better go quietly if you have not done any thing"—he still continued to resist, and threw himself down on the ground, but I succeeded in taking him to the station-house—in going there I observed Lambert, who was then in Conlan's custody, take some
thing from his coat pocket—I was behind him, with Donovan—I laid hold of Lambert's hand, and took this veil from it—I asked him where he got it—he said it was his sister's—I told Conlan to search him—he then be
came very violent again in the street, and both he and Donovan threw them
selves down—I did not see Conlan search Lambert—I searched Donovan, and found a sovereign in his fob pocket, and a crown-piece and five half-crowns in his right-hand trowsers pocket, three of which were new—I had a great deal of trouble to get them from him—Foster walked with us till we began to search Donovan and Lambert, and then he ran away—he had on a close-bodied claret-coloured coat, and a great-coat over his arm, which I think he has on now—he afterwards came to the station-house, about half-past eight o'clock, dressed as he is now—I do not know what had be
come of the claret coat—he had not got it on—I commenced searching him, and then he took his money out, and gave me—it was one crown
piece, a sixpence, three fourpenny-pieces, and 6d. In copper—there were no

shillings—I was at the station-house when a duplicate was shown to Donovan—he said it was his—I asked him what it was for—he said for a pair of boots, that they were his own boots, he had pledged them himself.
JURY. Q. Why not take Foster into custody at first? A. I had not sufficient strength—we had enough to do with the others.

EDWARD CONLAN (police-constable M 131.) I was in company with Woodhouse on Friday morning, the 25th of January—I searched Lambert, and found on him a pair of braces, a silver caddy spoon, four pieces of foreign coin—a pair of silver shirt-sleeve buttons, two five shilling pieces, two half-crowns, one quite new, a sovereign, some shillings, sixpences, and fourpenny pieces, and 1s. 51/2d. In copper—while we were taking Lambert and Donovan along, Foster said he would go on quietly, but as soon as I commenced searching Lambert, he went away—I cannot say whether he walked or ran away—he had a close-bodied claret coloured coat on—he came to the station-house about a quarter of an hour afterwards with a different coat on—I think he had the same great coat on his arm that he has on now.

Foster. I have sent for the coat I had on, it was not a claret—I know I changed my dress, but not in the way they speak of—what colour is claret? Witness. A dark brownish colour—I am sure it was a dark claret coat he had on, and he had on a different dress when he came to the station-house.

SOPHIA PILLOW . I am the prosecutor's wife. I was called up by my husband between six and seven o'clock on Friday morning, the 25th of January—I went into the kitchen, and saw the window wide open, and a pane of glass broken—I know this lace veil to be mine—I have had it many years—I have a white one which my sister worked from it of the same pattern—I have often worn it—it is rather a rusty colour—I had teen it within a week of the robbery—I kept it in the parlour drawer—I have not the least doubt it is mine from the pattern and colour.

JOHN PILLOW
re-examined. This caddy spoon is mine, it has the ini
tials of my first wife on it, "J A P"—this knife belongs to Mary Har
rison—these sleeve buttons are mine—they are engraved with my father's initials "E P," I have had them about two years—the braces I know are mine—I have not recovered any of the wearing apparel—there is pro
perty t o the amount of 2l. Not recovered—here is a silver rupee which I know perfectly well—there is no mark on it, but I had one and missed it—here is a small French coin, a Napoleon, which I have had for years, and a George the Second halfpenny—they are all mine.

EDWARD CONLAN
re-examined. The George the Second halfpenny, and the foreign coins were found on Lambert.

Lambert's Defence. I was going home about half past twelve o'clock at night, the policeman met me at the corner of a court by a public-house—he said, "Well, Bill, are you going home?"—I said, "Yes, and going to bed"—I went into the public-house first to have a pint of half-and-half, and when I came out, he said, "You might as well have given me half of it"—I took him in, and he had a glass of the best rum along with me—he then said, "You had better go home and go to bed"—I did so and he saw me in doors—I got up at half past six o'clock next morning, and going under
neath the rail-road, towards the Borough, I saw a lot of things under
neath the rail-road in different places, separate from each other—there was

a veil, a pair of braces, and a lot of coins—I picked them up, and put them in my pocket—I then came up as far as St. George's church in the Borough, and went into a public-house to have half a pint of coffee—I there saw Donovan—I sat down and got rather intoxicated—he wanted to see me home as I could not take myself home, and about nine o'clock, he took me into a cab, and I was taken by the policemen.

Donovan's Defence. I was coming home from my aunt's at Deptford at past twelve o'clock—I met Lambert, and said, I was very dry—he went into the public-house with me to have some half-and-half—the policeman was inside, and he said we might have given him some of it—we treated him with a glass of rum, and went home—when I got up in the morning, I was going for an errand to Whitechapel for my father, and met Lambert and Foster in a public-house—he treated me with some coffee there—we all three of us stopped there, got rather intoxicated, and I took a cab to see Lambert home, and two constables came and took us into custody.

Foster's Defence. On Thursday evening, about ten o'clock, I went into the King's Arms public-house in Kent-street, kept by Mr. Clark—I remained there till half-past three o'clock in the morning—I then came out, and went to the public-house where sergeant Featherton says he saw me at four o'clock—the doors were not open till a few minutes after four o'clock—there were some scavengers and several working men waiting there to get something to drink—I went in and staid there till half-past five o'clock, when Lambert and Donovan came in, and asked me to have something to drink—we had something, and soon after Lambert asked me if I would get him a cab to see him home—I got him one, and we rode as far as Unicorn-square, where Lambert's sister lives—he went in there, and came out again while Donovan and I were waiting outside—he said, "I shall not stop at home"—I told him he had better, as he was very fresh, and he would only get drinking, and if he had a shilling or two to take care of them—nothing would persuade him, and while we were talking, the policeman came up, and said they were his prisoners—they did not offer to take me, but took the other two—I walked four or five hundred yards along with them, and while they were searching Lambert and Donovan, I went into a public-house and had a glass of gin—I then went home to my landlady—I told her that Lambert and Jones were taken up while I was talking to them at their door, and I thought they would come and take me, so I would save them the trouble, and go and give myself up—I had a cup of coffee, and pulled off my coat, for I had been to the station-house several times before, and they knew I was rather a roughish customer—I went and gave my
self up—I have written several times to the landlord of the public-house in which I was until half-past three o'clock, but he will not come, because he is afraid of being fined for having his house open—if you will give me time to subpoena him, I could make him come and speak the truth—I do not mean to say I was not in the prisoner's company, but I am as innocent of the charge as a child unborn—I wish to ask Woodhouse whether he did not go and inquire where I was at the time the robbery was committed—he promised me he would.

JOHN WOODHOUSE
re-examined. I did go, and the publican where he says he had been until three o'clock, told me he left the house at twelve o'clock, and did not return at all.

ROBERT LIVERSEGE . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of Lambert's former conviction, which I got from the office of Mr. Lawson, Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—I was present at his trial—Lam
bert is the man who was then convicted in the name of Thomas Smith. LAMBERT—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Life. DONOVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—FOSTER—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

853.
JOSEPH HUDSON was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
Thomas Winkley, on the 10th of January, and cutting and wounding him upon his head, with intent to maim and disable him.—2nd COUNT, stating his intent to be to do him some grievous bodily harm.

THOMAS WINKLEY . I am a horse slaughterer, and live in Green-street, Borough. The prisoner has been in my service—I had occasion to discharge him, and afterwards preferred a charge of breach of the peace against him for threatening my life, but his wife interceded for him, and I did not prosecute—that is about three months ago—he lived in one of my little houses—I had taken proceedings to get possession of it, but had offered him no offence whatever up to the 10th of January—about a quarter to five o'clock on that evening, I was coming from my house to the opposite premises, and saw the prisoner coming up the street—he hallooed out, "Hoy, stop, I want you"—I was opening my gate, and he came up and knocked my hat off with a stick, and said, "How do you like that, where is Mr. Pople?"—(the pri
soner had been to my house in the early part of the day and ill-used me and Mr. Pople, who was in the house at the time, had rescued me from him)—I was in the act of stooping to pick my hat up, and he struck me across the head with this stick (produced) several times, as hard as he could—it broke on my head, and while doing so he said, "I have got a little sharper instrument that that for you"—I think it has been a prop—Brady, one of my men, came to my assistance, and led me out of the yard—the blows cut my head—I was almost drowned in blood—Mr. Newth attended me and is doing so still—I am forty-nine years old.

JOHN BRADY . I was at work in the prosecutor's yard on Thursday the 10th of January—I saw the prisoner come—he brandished this stick over his head, and requested Mr. Winkley to fetch Mr. Pople to him, that he was then prepared with a stick—he wished to fight the prosecutor, and said he was prepared with a sharper instrument if necessary—he knocked the prosecutor's hat off and said, "D—your eyes, what will you do now?"—while the prosecutor was in the act of picking up his hat, the prisoner struck him on the head with the stick, with all his might, three times—I do not know whether the blows all fell on his head, but some did, for I saw the blood flow in torrents from his head—I assisted him across the yard.

GEORGE ELISHA NEWTH . I am a surgeon, and live in Great Suffolk-street. I was sent for to the prosecutor, on Thursday evening, at five o'clock—I examined his head and found an extensive contused wound, about three inches long, bleeding very profusely on the left-side of the scalp near the temple—it appeared to be produced by a round blunt instrument, like that produced, it would produce just such a wound—he lost a considerable quantity of blood—in my judgment I should consider it a very serious

wound—he has hardly recovered the effects of it now—he has been under my care ever since—the skull was laid bare, it was a ragged braised wound. WILLIAM TAYLOR (police-constable M 14.) I was called to take the prisoner into custody—he was running up the street at the time, and went into a public-house—I followed him in, and as soon as he saw me he took up this stick to make a blow at me—I immediately took him by the collar and took the stick from him—I took him to the station-house, and found this clasp-knife on him.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going down Green-street that day, and saw Mr. Pople and Mr. Winkley standing together—I was rather in liquor
one of them, I do not know which, said, "Here comes this vagabond"—I asked them what made them call me a vagabond—the prosecutor said, "You scoundrel, get out of my sight"—I wanted to know the reason of his calling me that name, and he said to Mr. Pople, "Knock him on the head with your stick"—Mr. Pople hit me a blow on my head, and I stag
gered and fell, being drunk—I went away about ten yards and got a stick—I then returned and said, "Now I am ready"—I made a strike at Mr. Pople, and accidentally hit Mr. Winkley, but not intentionally—I made sure to hit Mr. Pople, and had no intention at all to strike Mr. Winkley.

THOMAS WINKLEY
re-examined. What he has stated is false—he came to me while I was in-doors—I went out to him, and he said, "I want to know about this 4l., and counting-house crack"—I had had my counting-house broken open about a week before, but bad never charged him with it—I said, "I do not want any thing to say to you"—he caught hold of my neck-cloth, and dragged me out into the street—Mr. Pople come out and said, "Do you want to murder the man?"—the pri
soner got up in a fighting attitude to Pople, and made a hit at him—Pople warded it off and struck him, but did not knock him down—he came up again to Pople in a fighting attitude, and Pople struck him on the side of the head with a stick—it was twenty minutes after that that he came with this stick and did what I have described—we had had our tea in the meantime—his house is about fifty yards from mine—Mr. Pople was not present when my head was cut—the prisoner could not have hit me by mistake.

RICHARD POPLE . I was at the prosecutor's house on the day in question—Mr. Winkley called me out, and I found the prisoner had got the pro
secutor on his back on the pavement, and had his hand at his throat—I rescued him—the prisoner then got up and began to fight with me, and I struck him—he then went away and I also—I was not present when the prosecutor was struck afterwards—he came to me with his head covered with blood.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

854.
JOHN FOLEY and
DANIEL HOLLAND were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of January, 1 leaden pump, value 2l., the goods of the
London and Southampton Railway Company, the masters of the said
John Foley.

MICHAEL JONES . I work for Mr. Francis, of Nine Elms, Battersea, and occupy a house in his garden, within a few yards of the London and South
ampton railway. On the 1st of January I saw, in a field belonging to the Company, and adjoining the railroad, a pump, two hods, a sack, an axe, and a piece of pipe—I returned and told the foreman, then went back, and saw the two prisoners, one with a quantity of lead in the hod, and the

other putting some into a sack—the pump was then cut up into small pieces—I had seen it whole twenty minutes before—I saw Foley put the lead into the sack—he was endeavouring to put the remainder into his hod, when I asked what he had got—he said he had nothing—I saw a chopper lying be
tween the prisoners—I took it up, and told them, as I knew what they had got, the first man that moved I would cut his legs off—they wished to go up the meadow, but I ordered them to put the lead down, and gave them both into custody—Foley ran away when we got into the main road, but I pursued and took him—Holland walked gently before me—I took them both into the yard, and delivered them to Pye.

CHARLES PTE . I am a constable of the rail-road. Foley works on the railway—they were both given into my custody—I went to the place, and found the pump cut in pieces—I knew it to be the Company's pump—I had seen it within a week—Holland works for the contractor.

JAMES KENNERLY . I am a constable of the Southampton railway. The prisoners were brought into the station-house—I found a hammer at Holland's lodging, in Vauxhall-road—Foley gave his address in South Lambeth-buildings—I could find no such place, but I found he lived in Alpha-court—I there found an axe and hammer—when I came back I asked him why he gave me a wrong address—he said he did not know the name of the place—I asked if it was in Alpha-court—he said he believed it was.

JAMES WALKER . I work on the Southampton railway, and am a car
penter. This is my chopper. I left it safe in the basket on the works, on the 1st of January, in a building which I was roofing.

WILLIAM HAMMERSTON . I am a carpenter on the Southampton rail
way. This is my axe—the last time I saw it was on the 30th of October—I had met with an accident, and did not go to work after that for five weeks.
CHARLES CONSTABLE . I am a carpenter on the railway. This hammer is mine—I left it on the works—I was away for a month.
GEORGE WILLIAM EDGECOMB . My father is a carpenter on the railway. This small hammer is mine—I left it in my father's counting-house.
(The prisoner Foley put in a written defence, stating that he had found the things in the field.)

Holland's Defence. As I was coming home, at four o'clock, I picked up the hammer on the road—I did not know who it belonged to—I thought it not worth advertising, and left it at my house—I know nothing at all about the pump.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

FOLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 40.

HOLLAND—
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Confined Six Months.

855.
HENRY GEORGE GIBBONS was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of January, 1 watch, value 1l., the goods of
Jonathan White.

ELIZA WHITE . I am laundry-maid at Foster-house, Egham, which is a lunatic asylum. On the 8th of December the prisoner visited Ann Collins, a fellow-servant of mine there—he also spent New Year's-day there, and slept there—he came again on the 6th of January, and went out with Collins, to whom he appeared to be paying his addresses—I had a trunk in the laundry, containing wearing apparel, and some silver—about six o'clock I missed a

watch belonging to my brother Jonathan White from the laundry, and found the things in my box tumbled—I missed 28s. In silver—I missed the watch about six o'clock—I should know it again—there was a small jeweller's gold ring fastened to the handle—the number of the watch is 6608, and the maker's name is Lee.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When had you seen it last? A. Be
tween twelve and one o'clock on the 6th of January—I saw the prisoner there between two and three o'clock that afternoon—he remained there about an hour and a half—there was no one else there but the domestics.

HENRY BRITTON . I am servant to Mr. Watts, a pawnbroker, in Angel
terrace, King-street, Hammersmith—this watch was pawned by Mary Langston, who is not here, in the name of "Ann Gibson."

ANN COLLINS . I am a servant at the Asylum, I know the prisoner—on the 6th of January I saw him there in the kitchen—I left him alone in the laundry for about an hour—I never saw the watch in his hands.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he keep company with you when he came there? A. Yes; he went into the laundry, out of the rain—the box was in the laundry—there was no one else there that I know of.

RICHARD GOLDING . I am a policeman. I received information on the 28th of January, and a bag was given to me, at the George-inn, Hammer
smith, by Mr. Battersbee, who is not here—on examining it I found the duplicate of a watch in it—Langston is in prison for illegally pawning.

HENRY BRITTON
re-examined. That is the counterpart of the duplicate—I saw the prisoner at my master's premises a few days after, but not on this occasion.
RICHARD BROWN . I know the prisoner had that bag when he lodged with me at No. 2, Little College-street, Westminster—I never saw the bag at Egham.
NOT GUILTY .

856.
HENRY GEORGE GIBBONS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of January, 1 cloak, value 8s., the goods of
Vincent Prosper.

ROBERT WEARE . I am keeper at Dr. George Burrows's establishment at Clapham. About four o'clock on the evening of the 15th of January, I saw two cloaks safe at the house—one belonged to Mr. Vincent Prosper—I did not notice it again that day—I missed it about seven o'clock next morning—this is it—(looking at it)—the prisoner had lived in the establish
ment as a keeper, but had left on the 8th of November—he had come on the 22nd of October—the police were sent for, and examined some footmarks—they were those of a person who wore straps—I gave directions to the policeman, and the prisoner was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Who is Mr. Vincent Prosper? A. A patient there—the cloak was behind the door in the hall when I last saw it—I saw it on the 15th, as the patient had it on that day—I did not see it hung up—I saw it after the patient had it, about four o'clock in the afternoon—the prisoner's boots and straps were compared with the foot
marks, two days after, when he was taken, and they exactly corresponded—there had been a board placed over the marks—I found that still there—the boot was first placed on one side, and then in the mark—there was no other mark made.

RICHARD GOLDING . I am an officer. I was sent for, and received a communication from Were—I went into the garden, and observed foot
marks near the house, which appeared to have been made by a person wearing straps to their trowsers—I made inquiry, and from information,

suspected the prisoner—on the 18th I saw him in custody at Queen-square office, with this cloak on—I took it from him, and these boots and straps were taken from him—I went with my brother constable, and examined them with the marks, and from the circumstance of their being overtrod here, I put it in, but not to make any pressure—they exactly corres
ponded—I put it to the side first—I did not make another impression.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he account for where he got the cloak? A. Not at that time, he said, at the next examination, that he had bought it.

ROBERT WEARE
re-examined. I have examined the cloak carefully—it is Vincent Prosper's, I have not the least doubt of it.

MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know it by? A. have seen it for five or six months—I have been in the habit of putting it on the gentleman myself—I brought the gentleman from on board a ship, and here are marks I know it by, at the time I brought him from the vessel—there is a button which is broken at the bottom, and it is stained, as the gentleman was rather dirty, and is in the habit of blowing his nose on it, and wetting it, and there are marks of it—I have not the least doubt it is his.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Transported for Seven Years.

857.
ELIZABETH SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of February, 175 yards of flannel, value 14l. 10s., the goods of
Martin At
kinson.

ALFRED BRADLAND . I am shopman to Martin Atkinson, of Bridge-road, Lambeth. On the night of the 6th of February, rather before seven o'clock, I missed this flannel from about four feet within the door—I saw the prisoner with it, and took her about three yards from the door—she said it was not he that took it—it was partly covered with her cloak.
WILLIAM DAVEY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge—she said a young man, in company with two females, gave it to her to carry, and promised to pay her.

Prisoner. I had no thought it was stolen—two females gave it to me, who I had seen about the street before—I had not got it under my cloak. Witness. She had carried the flannel a very little way, it was very heavy.

MR. BRADLAND re-examined. She had both arms round it, and it was partly covered with her cloak—I saw several persons about—she said she would point out the person who gave it her, but finding it on her, I kept her.

WILLIAM DAVEY
re-examined. I have reason to suspect the other per
sons, they are thieves—I got their names from the prisoner—I have made inquiries about her, and have heard nothing against her before—she gets her living by selling dolls about in a basket.
NOT GUILTY .

858.
ELLEN SAGGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of January, 1 purse, value 2d.;1 sovereign, 1 shilling, and 1 £5 Bank note, the goods and monies of
Frances Maria Kitchener, in the dwelling-house of Charles Ernest Rack witz.

FRANCES MARIA KITCHENER . I am a widow of an officer in the navy. I have a pension of 40l. a-year, and live in Westminster Bridge-road, Lam
beth,

in the house of Charles Ernest Rackwitz, a baker. I have known the prisoner eighteen or twenty years—we were in the habit of visiting each other—her husband holds a respectable situation in Doctor's-commons—on Monday, the 14th of January, I changed a cheque at Barclay's bank—my landlady was with me, and she took the money, all but 5s., which she gave me—the money was a £10 note, three £5 notes, and a sovereign—after I got home, I paid my landlady the £10 note, and two of the £5 notes—I put the sovereign into the other £5 note, and put them together into my purse, which I put into my pocket—I afterwards put it into my table-drawer in my front room—the drawer was not locked—that was between four and five o'clock in the afternoon—the prisoner was in my room at the time—she came about four o'clock, and drank tea with me—I gave her 2s. To fetch a loaf from below, and we had a little gin and water together about seven o'clock I said to her, "I am very tired, and if you will excuse me, I will go to bed"—I was fatigued with the walk in the morning—she said, "I will go up stairs with you"—she did so, and assisted me to bed she wished me good night, stooped over the bed and kissed me, and went away—I heard the private door slam—I did not go to sleep, but about ten minutes after, I got out of bed, put on my shoes and cloak, and went down stairs to get my purse out of the table-drawer, but it was gone—I am quite sure I had put it into the drawer.

Cross-examined by MR. CLABKSON. Q. Had you and the prisoner met together a good deal lately? A. No; she came whenever she found it con
venient—we were not in the habit of writing to each other—I never intrusted her with my money to take care of—we were intimate—I lodged with her mother three years—I took nothing after tea on this night—we had sixpenny-worth of gin and water between us before tea, just after the prisoner came, which was four o'clock—it was two glasses, I believe, it was not nearly half a pint—I frequently have a little gin and water after dinner, not always—I had taken a little porter at my dinner—I took nothing that did me any harm, I was perfectly myself—I do not usually go to bed so early as seven o'clock, except from fatigue or illness—I had no punch-bowl in the house that night—I did not ask the prisoner to go up stairs with me, she offered to do so—I did not put the £5 note into any punch-bowl, or any basin—I put it into my purse, and in the table-drawer—I did not put it into the slop-basin at tea—the prisoner went away about half-past seven o'clock, and I got out of bed about ten minutes after—I went down, as I fancied I had mislaid my money, and wished to be sure—I searched in the closet, under the sofa, and in the boxes, and every where I could think of, I was full an hour searching—I then went to bed again—I did not call up my landlady, but she came up to me.

WILLIAM VICKRESS . I keep the White Hart, in the Walworth-road, about half or three quarters of a mile from the prosecutrix. On the 14th of January, between seven and ten o'clock in the evening, I gave the pri
soner change for this note—I knew her before, and have not a doubt of her being the person—I knew her name, and put it on it myself—I have written "Sagger, Manor-place, 14 January, 39"—I afterwards paid the note to the Excise.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known her? A. From twelve to eighteen months, she is the wife of a very respectable man—I was standing at the desk when she came in, and asked for change—I am not aware that

I changed any other £5 note that day, but I cannot be certain, I only sur
mise the time, I fancy it was after tea—my attention was not called to this for nine days—I had forgotten the transaction then, except by the parties referring to some money I had paid to the Excise—I had paid sixteen guineas to the Excise—I think it was three £5 notes—I paid it, I think, the Wednesday after I took the note—I could not have written the name and address on either of the other notes, for I wrote it when the prisoner changed it—I did not notice whether I wrote names on the other notes—I have written Mr., not Mrs. Sagger, on this note—I knew her to be a married woman—it was written in her presence—I said,."Your name is Mrs. Sagger, I believe," and she said, "Yes"—I was certain of her person, but not exactly of her name at the time—I had sent goods to her house, and knew her as a customer.

WILLIAM SILK . I am clerk to Barclay and Co. I have not my books here—I have brought the numbers of the notes which I paid the progecu
trix—I made the entry in the book.

MARIA CATHERINE RACKWITZ . I went with the prosecutrix to the Bank, on Monday, the 14th of January. She received a £10 note, three £5 notes, a sovereign, and five shillings there—I took charge of the money—when I got home, I gave it all up to her, except five shillings, which she had at first—she paid me £10 and two £5 notes—she took the sovereign, and rolled it up in the other £5 note—I have the numbers of the notes, which I got from the banker's.
NOT GUILTY .

859.
EDWARD DELVES BROUGHTON was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Charles Flower Mirfin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Death recorded.
(MR. CHAMBERS, On behalf of the prosecutor, strongly recommended the prisoner to mercy. See Cowan, Mayor, Eleventh Session, page 904.)

860.
SUSANNAH WELLER, alias Sarah Miller,
was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of December, at St. Giles, Camber well, 1 pair of ear-rings, value 7l.;1 necklace, value 5s.; 1 purse, value 3d.;1 collar, value 2s.; 1 flounce, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 waistband, value 1s.; 1 shop, value 1s.; and 1 pocket-book, value 6d.; the goods of
William Small, her master, in his dwelling-house.

JOHN BOURN . I am foreman to Messrs. Mullens, pawnbrokers, of Sta
verton-row, Newington. On the 31st of December the prisoner came and offered me a pair of diamond ear-rings to pawn, and a gilt snap—I saw what the ear-rings were, and asked what she wanted for them—she said 4s.—I asked how she came by them—she said she bought them in Wilton
ler, shire, and gave 3s. for them—I asked what her name was—she said Wel and she lived in Cold-harbour-lane—I felt satisfied they were not hers, and gave, her into custody—the ear-rings are worth 7l.

CELIA ROUBEL SMALL . I am the wife of William Small. We live in Hill-terrace, Grove-lane, in the parish of St. Giles, Camberwell—the prisoner was my nursery-maid for about seven weeks. These are my ear-rings—I missed them on the 27th of December, four days before she offered them to pawn, but I did not mention it to her, as I had no suspicion of her—they

were taken from a box in a glass-drawer in my bed-room—these other things are mine—this purse was taken from ray work-box, and this collar from one of the children's drawers; this flounce from a closet, and the other things from different drawers—they were all found on the prisoner.
THOMAS HOOKWAY (police-constable P 13.) I was sent for, and took the prisoner—I found these things on her, which the prosecutrix has identified.
Prisoner. I did not take the ear-rings from my mistress's drawer.

GUILTY . Aged 17—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Transported for Ten Years.

861.
DENNIS WALEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of Janu
ary, 1 waistcoat, value 4s., the goods of Joseph Nun wick Rosier.

JOSEPH NUNWICK ROSIER . I keep a pawnbroker's shop in Tooley-street. On the 19th of January I attached this waistcoat to a coat inside my shop, and in about half an hour I missed it—I sent to different pawn
brokers, and at the shop of Mr. Bulworthy we found the prisoner offering it in pawn.

THOMAS BARRETT . I am an apprentice to Mr. Bulworthy, a pawn
broker. On the 19th of January the prisoner offered this waistcoat in pawn—Mr. Rosier's lad came and asked about it, and I detained the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I came out of a public-house, and saw two men, one of whom had got a waistcoat—he asked the other to buy it, but he had no money—he then asked me—I wanted one, and tried it on—he wanted 3s. for it—I gave him all I had, which was 2s.—then as I had not a farthing left, I went to pawn it.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

862.
HENRY HOWARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Ja
nuary, 1 coat, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
John Andrew Lyon; and 2 coats, value 2l. 5s., the goods of Washington Lyon.

JOHN ANDREW LYON . I am the brother of Washington Lyon, who lives with me in the Kent-road. On the 17th of January, at seven o'clock in the morning, I saw the parlour window open—my attention was drawn to it by my mother, who was the first up—the coats and a cloak were gone from the passage—there had been one coat of mine and two of my brother's—the cloak had been taken from there, but was left in the parlour, near the window, which had been got up by some force—we went out, and saw a strange footmark on the garden-beds—this is my coat, and these are my brother's.
FRANCIS PATRICK (police-constable P 233.) I was on duty at eight o'clock that morning, and met the prisoner in the Kent-road, with another man—the prisoner had these coats on him—I took him.

JOHN COLES (police-constable M 78.) I saw the prisoner taken—the other man had this Petersham great-coat on his arm—the, prisoner had these other two—the bill against the other man was thrown out.
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

863.
JOHN JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of January, 61bs. weight of beef, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
James Smith.

JAMES SMITH . I am a butcher, and live at Cambenwell. My young man in going out with the cart lost a piece of beef, this is it—(looking at it)—it was found in an oven partly cooked—I know it is mine—it is my own cutting out of a loin.

ABRAHAM PUTLEY . I live with the prosecutor. I was sent out with some meat on the 19th of January—I went to a house at Vauxhall to leave some, and then I missed this piece of beef—the prisoner was near ray cart at the time I left it—he said at Union Hall that he found it by the side of the cart—it could not have fallen out.
JAMES HOOPER (police-constable P 83.) I was called on the 20th to take the prisoner's mother—she had this meat in her possession partly cooked—I do not know whether he lives in her house.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it all over dirt—I washed it and took it to my mother.
NOT GUILTY .

864.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of January, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Peyton Ban
bury, from his person.

THOMAS PEYTON BANBURY . I am a clerk to a solicitor. On the 25th of January, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, I was near the Town Hall, in High-street, Borough—I felt a tug at my pocket—I turned and saw the prisoner pulling my handkerchief from my pocket, and putting it down by his right side—I collared him and asked him for my handkerchief—he said he had not got it—he dropped it, and pulled me from one side of the street to the other—he struck at me and fined to get away, but I never let him go—the officer came and took him.

Prisoner. When you turned the handkerchief was on the ground, and you asked a gentleman if he saw me take it—he said be did not. Witness. I saw the handkerchief in your hand—there was a gentleman who saw me struggling with the prisoner, and he said, "Hold on to him, young man," and when the prisoner was taken, I said to the gentleman, "Did you see him take it?"—he said, "No, I did not"—the prisoner stuck his nails into my hand.

JAMES GIRLING (police-constable M 112.) I saw the prosecutor strug
gling with the prisoner—the prosecutor's hand was bleeding—I took the prisoner, and a young woman took up the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

865.
EDWARD PARKER was indicted
for forging and uttering, on the 28th of January, a request for the delivery of 2 bars of solder and a piece of lead, with intent to defraud
Charles Edward Matthews and to
other; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Years.

866.
GEORGE HALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Ja
nuary, 1 cask, value 145., the goods of
Thomas Bryon.

THOMAS BRYON . I am a publican, and live in York-street, Lambeth. On the 24th of January, the policeman applied to know if I had lost a rum puncheon—I missed one from a passage by the side of the house, where I had a number of casks—this is it—(looking at it.)
JOHN COOPER (police-constable M 106.) On the 22nd of January, about half-past eight o'clock in the morning I was sent for, as the prisoner was

hawking this cask for sale at a cooper's shop—I went there—the prisoner was in the yard—I said, "Whose is this?"—he said it was his own—I said, "You are hawking it very early?"—he said he had a witness at the Angel who knew that he bought it—he then said he bought it at the Bell, at Wandsworth—I went there, and the landlady said it was no such thing.

Prisoner's Defence. I said if he would come to the Angel he would know further about it—he said, "You shall not go there, you shall go to the station-house"—a young man took me in there and gave me some rum he said he had a cask he had bought at the Bell, in East-lane—he said, "What is it worth?"—I said about 13s.—I went to the cooper's and took it, they would not give me 13s. for it.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

867.
JOHN WAGSTAFF was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of January, 2 bottles, value 4d., and I quart of wine, value 4s., the goods of
William Sandom—2nd COUNT, stating it to belong to
Frank Thomas.

JOHN BEZANT . Mr. William Sandom is a captain in the navy—I am servant to Frank Thomas, a lighterman—this wine was in my master's warehouse. On the 24th of January the prisoner came there rather drunk—he came to take the rope in, and he said to me, "Will you take this rope in, as I am afraid I shall fall?"—he then said, "I am going up stairs"—I said, "What for?"—he said, "I must go up"—he went, and I went after him to No. 3—I there heard him hustling among the wine—I went down to the foreman, and when I went up again he had got to No. 5, near to a bag of hops—he came out, and I saw a bottle of wine in his pocket—the foreman asked him what he had got there—he said he had picked it up from behind the bag of hops—he gave it to the foreman.

SAMUEL WILMOTT . I am foreman to Mr. Thomas. I went up stairs with Bezant—the prisoner had a bottle of wine in his pocket—he was drunk—he was in the service of Wood, Field, and Wood, hop-merchants—we warehouse hops for them, and he had come that day with some hops—I found another bottle of wine behind the bags of hops, one he gave me out of his pocket, and two more were found at his lodging—I know these bottles by the marks on the corks—my master had the care of them.
JOHN GASKIN . I am an officer. I was called to take the prisoner—I went to his house, and found some wine there.
FRANK THOMAS . I am a lighterman. I was sent for, and gave the prisoner in charge—this is the wine, it was left in my care.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw the bottle standing by the bag of hops—I took it up, but did not think about thieving.
GUILTY . Aged 45.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Weeks.

868.
HENRY HINCKLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of December, 2 half-crowns, the monies of
George Webb, his master.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE WEBB . I am a cheesemonger, and live at Lambeth-walk. The prisoner was in my employ for about eight months—on the 28th of December I marked three half-crowns—(I have one till for gold, and three for silver and copper)—I put the three half-crowns into a till on the cheese and bacon side, about half-past twelve o'clock—the prisoner had access to the whole

of my tills—I went to it again about three o'clock in the afternoon, and the three half-crowns were gone—on the 7th of January I marked seven sovereigns and four half-sovereigns—I gave them to George Seymour, to put through the slide into the gold till, which is generally kept locked, hut on that occasion I left it unlocked on purpose—it is under the butter coun
ter, and the shopman put the gold into it, through the slide, about twelve o'clock—I had previously seen Mr. Wheeler, a coal-merchant, and gave him instructions, and at half-past one o'clock I saw Mr. Wheeler's ser
vant come to the shop—I had given Seymour orders to go to dinner at that time, and I left the shop, leaving the prisoner in it—I said to him, "Mind the shop; I am going into the Borough"—I went out, and returned in about half an hour—the prisoner was just then going down to dinner, and the others were just coming up from dinner—I went to a silver till, and missed about 1l. worth of silver, which I had left in it—I then went to the gold till, and found the same number of sovereigns I had left in it, with no addition—I sent for a policeman, and went down, and said to, the prisoner, "You have robbed me of a sovereign"—he said, "I have not"—I said, "You have taken one, and it is not in the till"—I then said, "Policeman, you must take him; I am sure he has got it"—the prisoner said he had not—I sent for the gold till, and there were only seven sovereigns and four half-sovereigns in it—I sent for Mr. Wheeler and the servant—I said, "Mr. Wheeler, I believe you sent a sove
reign over for some bacon?"—he said, "I did, by my servant"—the ser
vant said, "I paid it to this young man"—the policeman then searched the prisoner, but found no sovereign—I then said, "Give up the sovereign, you vagabond, and go about your business"—he persisted that he had not got it—I said, "I am satisfied you have got it, I do not care whether you pro
duce it or not"—after some time he said, "You say if I give you up the sovereign I am to go about my business"—I made no answer, but said to the policeman, "Take him away and lock him up"—he took him up stairs—he went behind the counter as I thought for his hat, but he threw down the sovereign and said, "There is your sovereign"—I said, "This is not the first sovereign you have robbed me of, I am satisfied you have robbed me to a great extent"—he then pulled out five shillings, and declared that was all the money he had got—I said, "Previously to your being locked up I shall see your box"—he went up stairs and then said he had not got the key of his box—I told the policeman to break it open, but I believe the prisoner opened it with a key—the policeman found ten sovereigns in the breast pocket of a coat in the hot—the prisoner said, "That is mine"—I said, "Take possession of it, policeman"—I then said to the prisoner, "Have you any more?"—he said, "No"—the policeman searched further and found thirteen packages of silver, and amongst it I found two of the half-crowns which I had marked on the 28th of December, and one that I had marked previously—on the way to the station-house I said to the prisoner, "Don't you think you are a pretty fellow to rob me?"—he said, "I am not the only one that is robbing you"—I have six other persons in my employ.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you certain you are correct in that phrase? A. Yes.

WILLIAM WHEELER . I am a coal-merchant, and live in Lambeth-walk. I marked a sovereign and called my servant out of the kitchen and told her to take particular notice of it—my sister told her to go and purchase some
thing
—she went out and brought back lbs. 10d., and a piece of bacon—I was sent for to Mr. Webb's and saw the same sovereign—the prisoner picked it up from under the counter, and threw it on the counter.

ROBERT CREASY (police-constable L 172.) I went to Mr. Webb's on the 7th of January, and saw the prisoner sitting at dinner down stairs. Mr. Webb charged him with stealing a sovereign—he said he had not—in consequence of the conversation which took place, I went up to the shop—I then saw the prisoner feeling under the counter, and he produced a sovereign—I went to his box, and found ten sovereigns and thirteen packages of silver—Mr. Webb said he had marked some half-crowns and missed them, and if they were there he could identify them—he picked out these marked ones.
MR. WEBB. These are two of those I marked on the 28th, and this is one I marked before—I can swear to them.
(Michael Delaney, a tailor, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

869.
ELIZABETH WEST was indicted
for stealing, on 17th of Ja
nuary, 2 handkerchiefs, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Wharton and
John Wharton; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE TRAVELL . I am shopman to Henry and John Wharton, pawn
brokers, in Bermondsey-street. On the 17th of January the prisoner pledged a gown for half-a-crown—as she was going out my attention was drawn to her—Bennett fetched her back, and two handkerchiefs dropped from her—the officer was passing at the time—the prisoner was very vio
lent, and in dragging her into the shop a gown-piece fell from her—I de
livered the handkerchiefs to the officer—these are them—they are my mas
ters'—they had been hanging two yards and a half inside the shop when the prisoner came in.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. When had you seen them? A. About five minutes before—there is no mark on them.

ROBERT BENNETT . I am shopman to Messrs. Wharton. I saw the prisoner in their shop on the 17th, and followed her out—I brought her back, and on the way she droped this black silk handkerchief—the boy picked it up, and brought it to her—she said it was not hers—this other handkerchief I took from under her cloak—she struck me on the head—I dropped the handkerchiefs in the scuffle, and they were taken up by another person.
JOHN KELLY (police-constable M 85.) I took charge of the prisoner and the articles.

HENRY TRITON (police-constable M 175.) I know the prisoner, and was present at Newington, in 1836, when she was tried—I have the cer
tificate of her conviction from the Clerk of the Peace's office—(read.)
GUILTY .* Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

870.
JAMES BAILEY was indicted
for bigamy.

MARY SHREEVE . I am a widow, and live in Seymour-place, Maryle
bone. I am the mother of Elizabeth Bailey—I remember her being mar
ried to the prisoner at the parish church of St. Mary Magdalen, Bermond
sey, on the 5th of January, 1816—I was present, and witnessed it—I saw my daughter yesterday.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Did they continue to live together? A. Yes, but not in my house—I heard of his second wife going to live with them, but I never saw her there—I know nothing of the second marriage.
DEBORAH BRADFIELD . I was married to the prisoner on the 12th of June last, at the parish church of St. Mary, Newington.

Cross-examined. Q. You were married by banns? A. Yes—I had been living at the prisoner's two months before—his wife lived in the same house—I knew he had a wife—I was in the family-way by him, and it was proposed that we should marry, that the child should be legitimate, and that I might get a situation as wet nurse if I could show my marriage
register—his wife knew of it—I had no wish to prosecute him.

GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined Three Months.

871.
JOHN TERRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of January, 3 spoons, value 4l., the goods of
James Paul, his master.

JAMES PAUL . I live in Bermondsey, and am a surgeon—the prisoner was my errand-boy for about five weeks. On the 1st of January, I had a party, and the next morning I missed three spoons—I had the prisoner apprehended on the 9th, and told him if he would tell me where they were I would let him go home, as I wanted to make my set complete—I have never found them, but I have traced where they went to, and he confessed to having stolen them.
NOT GUILTY .

872.
EDWARD PEARCE was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Richard Hodgson, on the 21st of January, and stabbing and wounding him on his left arm with intent to maim and disable him.—2nd COUNT, stating his intent to be, to do him some grievous bodily harm.

RICHARD HODGSON . I am a broker's assistant. On the 21st of January I was employed by Mr. Turner, of Friar-street, Blackfriars-road, to make a distress on the prisoner's premises, No. 2, Hebden-court, Pearl-row. Blackfriars-road—I went there about half-past two o'clock in the after
noon—I met Prettyman the landlord at the door—the prisoner was only a tenant—I sent the landlord up first, and then went in myself—I went up to the prisoner's room, and found him sitting on a stool at work, conversing with the landlord—he is a shoemaker—the landlord was saying to him, "I wish you to settle this little thing without putting me to the trouble of putting a distress on your goods—I wish you to do it"—the prisoner said he had no money to settle it—I then said to the prisoner that a duty would devolve on me which I was very reluctant to perform on a man in his situation, but without he and the landlord could settle it, I was there with a warrant to distrain his goods—I held the warrant in my hand, and showed it to him—on my doing so, he said, "You are not going to rob my poor children of my poor bits of things?"—I said, I was very sorry, but I had a duty to per
form which I could not help—he immediately turned round to the left side of him, and snatched a knife from the seat on which he was at work—it was such a knife as shoemakers use—he rose up from his seat, swore a tremendous oath, and requested me to leave the room, holding the knife up in an attitude to plunge it at me—I said, "My good man, do lay such a dangerous instrument as that down, I have not come here to do you any harm"—I requested him two or three times to lay it down—he then turned

to his seat again, and snatched up a hammer—in the interim I looked round to get something—I saw a child's cradle, and just as he was coming forward to strike me with the knife, I got it up and put it between us—he got hold of the other side of the cradle, lifted it up, and instantaneously sprang under the cradle, and made a plunge at me—I put my arm down to keep the knife from my side, and received it just above my elbow—it was a job under the cradle—I did not know the knife had entered my arm at the moment, till I perceived the blood flow—I then immediately felt a pricking pain—I turned the cradle round, and said—"You have committed a very serious act upon me,"—he made no reply—I moved the cradle round, went and seized him by the shoulder and the back of his trowsers, shoved him out of the room, and shut the door against him—I did not observe what he did with the knife—he came back again after I had closed the door, and requested to have his coat—I opened the door a little way, and perceiving he had not the knife or hammer, I allowed him to take his coat—he was in the act of going—I said he had no occasion to go, I should certainly give him into custody—he went away—I followed him, and he made a sudden rush into a house to escape—I went after him—a lad went for a policeman, who came, and I saw the prisoner taken in a water
closet, about twenty minutes after I had received the stab—I did not hear precisely what he said to the policeman, as the person in the house rescued him from me, but he said it was a very bad job, or something like it—Mr. Staddon, the doctor, has attended me—I was obliged to have my arm laid open—I am not well now, but am getting better.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you done every thing the doctor desired you? A. Yes—I have not been drinking spirits—the prisoner said to the policeman, when he took him, that he had done a very bad act, and he did not know how he came to do it—I did not bear him say that the knife touched my arm in the scuffle, and he did not intend to do it; but I was in such a situation that I might not hear what be said—it was not while I was struggling with him about the cradle that I felt the pain, it was just after—(looking at his deposition)—this is my hand
writing.

Q. (Reading from his deposition)—"I did not feel it for the moment, but in struggling with him after, for the cradle, I felt pain."A. That it not true—it was after I dropped the cradle that I felt pain—I did not struggle with him for the cradle—I kept him off some time, and he was trying to get the cradle from me, to strike at me—I was distraining on him for 10s. 6d.—I did not notice how many children there were—I think I saw two, but I would not swear it—I do not think there were four—I was so flurried while I was there, that I do not know whether they were crying or not—I put my hand on a chair when I went in, to distrain upon it, but nothing else—there was a woman in the room—I think the prisoner had a shoe on his knee—he threw it down when he rose up from his seat.

COURT. Q. Might this have been done by his using his hand to struggle for the cradle, or did you see a distinct push made at you? A. He sprang under the cradle and did it—I saw it coming, which made me put my elbow down and receive it there instead of my side.

JAMES PRETTYMAN . I am a shoemaker; the prisoner occupied one room in my house—I employed Hodgson to distrain—I was in the pri
soner's room when Hodgson came in—he told the prisoner that he was very

sorry, he had got a very unpleasant office to do, but as regarded him he must perform it—the prisoner was sitting on the seat he works at—the prisoner said, "You don't mean to deprive my wife and family of my goods?"—Hodg
ton said he had got that job to do, and he must do it—the prisoner then said to me, "Do you mean to take my goods?"—I said, "I don't wish to take your goods, but I have given you warning to leave my house, and I must have my money"—he said his wife was gone out for some money—I said, "You have told me so often, I can't help that, you must leave the house to-day"—the prisoner got the knife to cut at Hodgson, and told him to leave the room—Hodgson told him to put such an instrument as that down—he still kept it in his hand—I flew to the door, and saw him take up the hammer, and at the same time Hodson picked up the cradle—I saw the prisoner stoop under the cradle, with the knife in his hand—I saw the knife was in his hand, as he was going under the cradle, and his arm was bent—Hodson was standing with the cradle in his hand—the knife was towards his side—I never saw the knife afterwards, but most shoemakers use a sharp-pointed knife—it was one he was at work with—I ran down stairs, and went for a policeman—I saw Hodgson again in about a quarter of an hour—his coat was then off, and his shirt was all covered with blood—the prisoner had lodged with me three months, at 2s. 3d. a week—10s. 6d. was due—he is a journeyman—I did not see Hodgson strike him at all.

JAMES CUDDY (police-constable L 20.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody, between three and four o'clock, on the 21st of January, in a privy—I Galled Hodgson, and asked if he was the person who committed the assault—he said, "Yes"—the prisoner said nothing—as we were going to the station-house, I said he was a foolish man to get himself into that trouble—he said it was a foolish thing, but in the irritation of the moment, seeing his children crying round him, and he having not a mouthful of victuals to eat, it so irritated him, that he did not think for the moment that the knife touched the man's arm, and it must have been in the scuffle.

JOHN STADDON . I am a surgeon. I was requested by Mr. Jeremy the Magistrate to examine Hodgson's arm, between four and five o'clock on the afternoon of the 21st of January—I discovered a wound near the elbow
joint of the left arm, produced by some sharp instrument—it appeared to have been a stab or thrust—I did not examine the depth of it then, but after it became necessary to lay the wound opts, it was discovered to be three inches deep, or more—it was above the elbow, and had passed be
tween the integuments up towards the shoulder—I think it was such a wound as might have been made with a shoemaker's knife—it is getting well now.

ELLEN SULLIVAN . I am the wife of a carver and gilder. I was in the prisoner's room when Hodgson came in—the prisoner was at work at his bench at the time—directly Hodgson came in he seized the cradle—the prisoner jumped up at the moment, with the knife he was at work with in one hand, and a boot in the other, and seised hold of the cradle—I did not observe whether he dropped the boot—I saw them struggle for the cradle—I think, from what I saw, that the blow was quite accidental—the prisoner has four children—there were three there—they were crying—I have known the prisoner eight or nine years—he has always borne the character of an honest, peaceable, unoffending man—he has been a long time out of work.

COURT. Q. Did you see the thing happen? A. Yes—they had a struggle, and both fell on the bed—I did not see the man's arm bleeding, for as Mr. Pretty man left the room I left also—I did not know he had been hurt—I did not notice whether the prisoner kept the knife in his hand all the time they were struggling for the cradle—I did not see him stoop down under the cradle, or hold the knife up—I am sure he did not hold the knife up at all—I cannot tell how this injury was done to Hodg
son, or at what time of the struggle.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 42.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Twelve Months.

873.
RICHARD HITCHCOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of February, 1 gelding, price 25l.;1 cart, value 8l.;1 set of harness, value 2l.;20 sacks, value 1l. 10s.;4 horse-cloths, value 4s.;1 bag, value 1s.; and 56 bushels of oats, value 9l. 9s.; the goods and property of
James Muggeridge.

JAMES WHOWALL (police-constable M 166.) I was in Tennis-court, King-street, Southwark, on Thursday, the 7th of February, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening—I saw a horse and cart standing still it was a very bye place, my curiosity was excited, and I hid myself where I could see the cart, but nobody could see me—in about ten minutes I saw the prisoner coming down a turning called Bowling-green-lane, and he look the mare by the reins—there was another man with him—the pri
soner then took the cart down Bowling-green-lane into King-street, and on to Maze-pond—I followed them—the other man saw me, and he went away—when the prisoner got to Maze-pond, he looked round and saw me—I then went and asked where he was going—he said, "Home"—I said, "What, are you the carman?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "Where is your whip?"—he said, "Up in the cart"—but there was no whip there—I said I should take him to the station-house—he said it was very hard, as he saw the horse and cart standing, and he was going to take it home; but he was going in the wrong direction—I asked him what was the direc
tion on the cart—he could not tell me, but I found on it the name of Mr. Muggeridge, Tottenham Court-road—the cart was then three or four miles from there, and the prisoner was going in a contrary direction—I took the mare and cart, and my brother officer took the prisoner.

Prisoner. He asked me if I was the carman—I told him "No, but I saw the horse and cart coming down King-street,"—I knew the owner, and was going to take it home. Witness. I am sure he said he was the carman.

JOHN ALLEN (police-constable M 87.) I was with Whowall—I took the prisoner—there was another person with him, who got away—I asked the prisoner where he found the cart—he said, "In the Borough," and shortly afterwards he said he was coming through Mermaid-court, and saw it standing, and was going to take it home—Tennis-court leads into Mermaid-court.

HENRY BRAMBLE . I am carman to Mr. James Muggeridge, a corn
chandler, in Tottenham Court-road. I was out with his cart on the 7th of February—there were fourteen sacks of oats in it, worth nine guineas—I left it in Earl-street while I went into a public-house to get some refresh
ment—I put the nose-bags on the horses—when I came out the horse and cart and oats was gone—the oats had come from Mr. Smith's, a wharfinger, at the end of Earl-street—my master has his oats landed there, and I went

to take them home—it was about half-past six o'clock when I left it—I saw the cart and oats again in the green-yard, in| the Southwark Bridge-road, at half-past ten o'clock the same night—it was my master's—I saw the mare in the stable.

JAMES WHOWALL
re-examined. I took the cart to the green-yard—I did not see any other horse and cart there—I left it about eight o'clock—the horse was put into the stable.

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

874.
JOHN CARSTLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Janu
ary, 1 pair of boots, value 16s., the goods of
Jonathan Hall.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
William Smith.

WILLIAM SMITH . I live at Fisher's-rents, Tanner's-hill, Deptford, and work for Jonathan Hall, the landlord of the Ship and Whale, at Rother
hithe. These boots belong to me—they were made for me—my master delivered them into my hands while I was at work, and if I lost them I was to make them good—I left them on Saturday evening, the 26th of January, in my master's tool-house, and on the Monday they were gone—the prisoner had worked there, but was discharged on the Saturday.

RICHARD JAMES MJORE . I live in Grove-lane, Deptford. I saw the prisoner at a beer-shop on the 28th of January—he said he had been at tide work, but did not mean to go any more, that he had pawned his boots for 5s., and he wanted to sell the duplicate, as he was going to tramp—I bought the duplicate, and sent a lad to get the boots out.
Prisoner. When I sold the duplicate I said I should have them again. Witness. I took them that he should not lose his work, but might have them again.

JOSEPH PHILLIPS . I live at Mr. Wilson's beer-shop—I got the dupli
cate from Moore, and got the boots out.
THOMAS SIMMONS . I am assistant to Mr. Greenleaf, a pawnbroker, at Deptford. The prisoner pawned these boots on the 26th of January, in the name of W. Knight, Tanner's-hill.
BENJAMIN LOVELL (police-sergeant R 15.) I found the prisoner at a lodging-house at Tanner's-hill—he said he had pawned the boots to get more beer, but he was drunk at the time.
Prisoner. They belonged to any man that worked in the yard; as much to me as to any one.

WILLIAM SMITH
re-examined. I was measured for them, when I was not using them, other men might use them, but there was only one man in the yard, besides me, who could wear them—the prisoner could not get them on.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Six Weeks.

875.
JAMES VINCENT MILLER was indicted
for embezzlement.

PETER ALEXANDER KING KENT . I am in partnership with my brother, we are patten-makers, and live in Brook-street, Lambeth. The prisoner was in our employ as commission-agent, and to receive orders—we paid him as he obtained the orders—he was to receive money on our account—it was his duty to bring back the whole money to me, and to receive the commission—on the 25th of January I packed up some clogs to go to. Mr. Pearce, in the Walworth-road—the prisoner was to take them, and to receive 17s.—he should have brought that to me when he returned, but he.
never returned—I did not see him again till I gave him in charge, about a fortnight after.
WILLIAM PEARCE . The prisoner solicited an order from me for some clogs. I gave him an order for a dozen pairs—he brought them on the 25th, and I paid him 17s. on account of his master.

JAMES PEPPER (police-constable £ 51.) I took the prisoner an the 5th of February, in Mint-street, Borough. I told him I wanted him for abscond
ing with his master's money—he said, "I know I took the money, but it was for want of bread—my master can't make a felony of it, it is a breach of trust."
Prisoner's Defence. I took home these clogs—previous to going, I asked for sixpence to get me something to eat, which was refused—I then said, "Lend me a penny," which was refused.

MR. KENT re-examined. This is partly true, but he had been paid the commission on these clogs previous to the order going in, because he pleaded distress—on the morning he speaks of, he wanted some more, and I would not let him have it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Weeks.

876.
JOSEPH STOWER was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, 2 scarfs, value 1l. 12s., the goods of
William Kingston and another, his masters.

JOSEPH HARVEY . I am in partnership with Mr. William Kingston, we are linen-drapers, and live in Westminster Bridge-road. The prisoner was our porter—be came on the 1st of December, and, as I understood, he was in very bad circumstances—we received information which lad us to sus
pect him, and on the evening of Monday, the 4th of February, I placed myself at a skylight from which I could have a view of that part of the shop where he and the other porter slept together—I went about eleven o'clock at night, and when I had been there some the minutes, I saw the other porter leave his bed-side, and go down stairs—I then saw the pri
soner go to a distant part of the warehouse to the shawl department—he returned with something under his arm—I saw the black fringe on his white shirt, and it appeared to me to be shawls which he had—he stooped down, folded up the shawls, and seemed to have great difficulty in getting them in somewhere, I fancy it was into a pocket—I went to the station-house, and requested the assistance of an officer, and at seven o'clock the next morning the officer came to our shop, and took him into custody
Mayor, our clerk, went down, and fetched up the prisoner's coat—I asked the prisoner if it was his—he said "Yes," and if he had had it that morn
ing—he said "Yes"—the policeman took these two shawls out of the pocket of that coat.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. IS it possible you could have made any mistake about the person who did this? A. No; they are scarfs, or long shawls.
SAMUEL MAYOR . I am clerk to the prosecutor. On the morning of the 5th of February, when the prisoner was taken, I saw the officer find these scarfs in his coat-pocket.

ROBERT BRODIE (police-constable P 132.) I went to the prosecutor's, and the prisoner was given into my custody—I took him up stain—a coat was produced, which be said was his, and these shawls were found in
it—I took him to the station-bouse, and there he began to cry, and laid he wished he had got into bed, and not taken the shawls, which were the first he had ever taken.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MARCH 4, 1839.
